Recommended Reading: Armstrong  M. & Taylor  S. (2020). Armstrong's Handbook of Human Resource Management Practice. Kogan Page.Rowold J. (2015) Human Resource Management. Springer Gabler  Berlin  Heidelberg.Stock-Homburg R.  Groß M. (2019) Personalmanagement. Springer Gabler  Wiesbaden.Torrington  D. Hall  L.  Taylor  S.  and Atkinson  C. (2020). Human Resource Management (11.Ed). Pearson.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Programme: BSc. Betriebsökonomie |BSc. Business Administration |BSc. Wirtschaftsinformatik |BSc. Business Information Technology |BSc. International Business Management |
Communication: The students are able to:communicate their research to a relevant target audience
Content: The International Student Projects (ISPs) deliver international  interdisciplinary  and experiential learning opportunities for students and staff from across our university. The projects occupy a key position in our management education and are supported by the highest levels of the School of Business. They are unique in that they are planned  managed and run by our bachelor students under supervision. Student Delegates work individually or in groups to participate in the ISP  module and write a paper investigating a topic related to that year's project theme  taking into account their own research and inputs from the preparatory expert seminar at home and further update their briefing based on onsite inputs and experiences.
Description: ?As a final-semester module  the Integration Module focuses on the analysis of business-related problems and the development of appropriate solutions. Previous knowledge acquired in the business management modules is applied in an integrated and holistic manner. Students complete this module when participating and contributing in one of the School of Business's prestigious International Student Projects.   In an intensive study experience the students are given the opportunity to investigate a region at first hand and access insights provided by local and international businesses  educational and cultural institutions and representative offices such as the Swiss Embassy and consulates. The module enables students to understand  experience and analyse the local environment and relations between Switzerland and the destination countries / regions by drawing on the contents of the module and integrating their learnings from the whole degree programme.
Judgement: ?The students are able to:weigh the relative importance and impact of the  drivers of a defined topic area and judge how changes in these drivers  may influence future developments in the field
Knowledge: The students:  research a defined topic using secondary and published sources (plus optionally expert interviews)explore the key socio-political  economic  cultural and  technological drivers in the target country/region and/or a defined topic area
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Listen actively in order to respond appropriatelyCommunicate with the clarity and (in)directness needed to convey the intended meaning Connect with collocutors successfully so they understand and are understoodCollaborate in various cultural settings  achieving specific and desired results
Content: Theory to better understand communication  cultural  and interpersonal interactionModels and tools for skilled communication in face2face and virtual situationsTeamwork skills and strategies Presentation skills: developing  organizing  and delivering
Description: ?Professionals increasingly find themselves working in diverse teams and in a variety of business settings  which requires a thorough understanding of issues related to interpersonal and intercultural communication. The module aims to develop students’ personal awareness  sensitivity to cultural diversity  and interpersonal and intercultural communication skills  which are essential for effective communication in an international workplace.
Judgement: ?Evaluate and choose an approach for successful communication  taking the setting  purpose  and collocutors' needs into a consideration
Knowledge: ?Identify and describe different perspectives in communication?Identify and describe different communication stylesIdentify barriers to successful interpersonal and intercultural communicationDescribe skills in interpersonal and intercultural communicationExplain factors that lead to successful collaboration Explain the role of perception and interpretation on communicationExplain communication theories and modelsExplain the dimensions of culture and how they impact communication Be aware of different types and purposes of communication
Recommended Reading: ?Selected texts - see moodle
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students ...can transfer results of a statistical analysis to a non-expert audience
Content: Probability calculus Random experiment  definitions of probability  events  exclusive and independent events  laws of addition and multiplication  conditional probability  Bayes theorem  combinatorial analysis  random sampling  Descriptive statistics Measurement levels  absolute and relative frequencies  frequency tables  graphics  empirical distribution function  location parameters (mode  median  mean)  dispersion parameters (range  standard deviation  variance  coefficient of variation  interquartile range)  quantiles. Probability distributions Random variables and distributions (binomial and normal distribution) Linear correlation and simple linear regression Bravais-Pearson correlation coefficient  Spearman correlation coefficient  spurious correlation  simple linear regression Analytical statistics Point estimation and standard error  confidence interval  checking distributional form  significance tests (t-test for independent samples  U-test)  bi-serial and partial correlation  contingency tables (chi-squared test  measures of association). Statistical analysis Statistical analysis with SPSS  R or Excel Economic applications Indices/time series and their economic applications
Follow up module: Business Intelligence Financial Mathematics and Analysis
Judgement: ?Students ... can use statistical techniques to derive judgements on significance of differences in variablescan read quantitative reports and comment on them
Knowledge: ?Students ...know how to classify statistical variables and the implication of different measurement levels on data evaluation techniquesknow basic visualization techniques and descriptive techniquesknow the differences between univariate and bivariate analysisknow different statistical distributions of a quantitative variable (Normal  t-Student  Poisson  Binomial and others)understand and the difference between parametric and non-parametric methodsknow different statistical tests and know their limitations
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students ...can describe their findings in a logical and structured way in a report
Content: ?Students choose module of last or current semester and reflect the practicability and the usefulness of the learning outcomes in their professional environment.  Process Modul Reflection Job Experience (as of FS2022): ??Students register themselves via ESP for the module "Reflection Job Experience" Beginning of November 2021. Students receive the access code via e-mail for the current moodle course 09. February 22. Students enroll in the moodle course as of 09. Februar 21. They enter the module they want to write a job reflection about in the moodle list. In addition  the lecturer who was responsible for the chosen module must be indicated until 28. February 22. If  for capacity reasons of the individual lecturer  you cannot reflect on your preferred module  alternatives will be sought bilaterally with the students concerned as of 07. März 22.  On moodle the final allocation is published until 09. March 22. Students send the disposition to responsible lecturer via Email until 04.April 22. The students upload their Reflection Job Experience paper on moodle until 11. June 22. For the reflection a work confirmation of 50% employment is required. Upload the certificate of employment on moodle. (Please do not send the document by email to the person responsible for the module) until 25. June 22. Students receive their grade information (pass/fail) and a short feedback in writing from the responsible lecturer mid July. The ECTS points  in case you have passed the module  will be depicted in the spring semester's transcript of records.
Description: ?Students establish relationships between their studies and their professional practice. They successfully accomplish combining studies and professional activities. They analyze the transfer effects between studies and working life. Students effectively apply the knowledge acquired in their studies to their daily practice and thereby consolidate and link what they have learned.    How the reflection is created: The basis for the reflection is a disposition with the following contentWhich activity is reflected? (Project  line activities  ...)Background about the company in form of a profileTopic of the reflection: A reflection refers to a clearly defined part of a module. The student describes the content of the module and in which form they were presented in class (teaching and learning methods).Provisional structure of the paper Reflection:Students describe in detail how the reflection took place  based on the inputs in the module. This can happen in different ways  for example by evaluating or examining a concept  a technology / software  implementing a pilot  etc. This is the core of the work.Outlook: The students briefly outline how this topic is pursued in the company.  The structure of the reflection depends on the module you want to reflect on. General recommendations are therefore not useful. Some layouts of outlines to different modules can help you. The full reflections are not generally available for data protection reasons.  10-15 pages (subdivision  bibliography  table  table of figures  annex not included) are required
Judgement: ?Students ...recognize the connections between what they have learned and their daily tasks at work. They can reflect on and compare them.
Knowledge: ?Students ...implement the knowledge acquired during their studies efficiently in their daily work
Title: Module Description

Communication: Die Studierendenkönnen ihre Erkenntnisse sachlogisch und strukturiert in einem Bericht beschreiben.
Content: ?Die Studierenden wählen ein Modul des vorhergehenden Studienjahres und reflektieren die Anwendbarkeit und den Nutzen des Gelernten in ihrem beruflichen Umfeld.
Description: Die Studierenden stellen Beziehungen her zwischen dem Studium und ihrer Berufstätigkeit. Die Studierenden bewältigen erfolgreich die Kombination von Praxistätigkeit und Studium. Sie analysieren die Transferleistungen zwischen Studien- und Arbeitsleben. Das während des Studiums erworbene Wissen setzen die Studierenden in ihrem Arbeitsalltag effizient um und vertiefen und vernetzen auf diese Weise das Gelernte. Wie die Reflexion erstellt wird: Als Grundlage für die Reflexion dient eine Disposition mit den folgenden Inhalten Welche Tätigkeit wird reflektiert? (Projekt  Linientätigkeit  ...)Hintergrund über die Firma in SteckbriefformThema der Reflexion: Eine Reflexion bezieht sich auf ein klar abgegrenztes Teilgebiet eines Moduls. Der Student beschreibt die Inhalte und in welcher Form diese im Unterricht präsentiert wurden (Lernformen).Provisorische Gliederung der Arbeit  Reflexion: Die Studierenden beschreiben im Detail auf Basis der Inputs im Modul  wie die Reflexion stattgefunden hat. Dies kann in unterschiedlicher Weise passieren  etwa indem ein Konzept  eine Technologie / SW evaluiert oder untersucht wird  ein Pilot implementiert wird etc. Dies ist der Kernpunkt der Arbeit. Ausblick: Die Studierenden skizzieren kurz  in welcher Weise dieses Thema in der Firma weiterverfolgt wird. Ablauf (das Modul findet nur im Frühlingssemester statt)      Prozess Modul Reflexion Berufspraxis (ab FS2022)??Studierende melden sich im ESP für das Modul «Reflexion Berufspraxis) an. Beginn November 21 Studierende werden per Mail über den Zugangscode zum aktuellen Moodle-Kurs informiert 09. Februar 22 Studierende melden sich in Moodle im Kurs an ab 09. Februar 22 Sie tragen in der Moodle-Liste  das Modul ein  über das sie eine Berufsreflexion schreiben möchten. Ausserdem muss die/der verantwortliche Dozierende angegeben werden  die/der das Modul geprüft hat. bis 28. Februar 22 Auf Moodle wird die vorläufige Zuordnung veröffentlicht:(Falls Kapazitätsengpässe einzelner Dozierender dazu führen  dass Sie Ihr Wunschmodul nicht reflektieren können  wird individuell mit den betroffenen Studierenden bilateral nach Alternativen gesucht.) ab 07. März 22 Auf Moodle wird die endgültige Zuordnung veröffentlicht  Am 09. Marz 22 Studierende senden die Dispositionen an die verantwortlichen Dozierenden. bis 04.April 22 Die Studierenden laden die Berufsreflexion auf Moodle. bis 11. Juni 22 Für die Reflexion ist eine 50ige Berufstätigkeit erforderlich. Laden Sie die Arbeitsbescheinigung auf Moodle. (Bitte schicken Sie das Dokument nicht per Mail an die Modulverantwortliche.) bis 25 Juni 22  Die Studierenden erhalten von den verantwortlichen Dozierenden die Information (Bestanden/nichtbestanden)und  ein kurzes schriftliches Feedback.  Mitte Juli Die ECTS-Punkte  in dem Fall  dass Sie das Modul bestanden haben  werden im Leistungsausweis des Frühlingssemesters ausgewiesen.
Judgement: ?Die Studierendenerkennen die Zusammenhänge des Gelernten und ihren täglichen Aufgaben im Arbeitsalltag. Sie können diese reflektieren und vergleichen.
Knowledge: Die Studierendensetzen das während des Studiums erworbene Wissen in ihrem Arbeitsalltag effizient um
Recommended Reading: ?Literatur aus dem Unterricht
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Module Name: ToBIT: Topics in Business Information Technology
Communication: ?Students ...learn to discuss their prepared topic with students in the same topic group critically. These seminar situation should be an opportunity to learn more about the topic in different views.
Content: In Tobit  each student choose a topic to investigate in depth. The student then summarizes the findings in a report  presentation (20 min) and discussion (10 min). The goal is knowledge transfer: distill the results of detailed research into the most important information  such as might be required by management  and to present this information understandably. (3.1 3.2)  Tobit is conducted as a seminar  and attendance is required at  the presentations of at least two other students. Tobit is an important part of the preparations for the bachelor thesis.
Description: ?Business information specialists face with new technologies and trends throughout their working lives. They must be able to acquaint themselves with new information quickly and independently  in order to evaluate these technologies and trends for use in their business. Moreover  many businesses are now international  and important internal meetings are conducted in English. The goal of Tobit is to reproduce this situation for students.
Judgement: ?Students ...The type of analysis required depends on the subject: assess the advantages and disadvantages of a technology  or the pros and cons of some new development should be a goal of the seminar. (2.1)
Knowledge: ?Students ...learn to understand new ideas. Each student receives a topic to prepare  and each topic is supervised by an instructor.
Recommended Reading: depends on chosen topic
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students ...… can communicate effectively within and about the project… can present effectively about the state of a project… use project management terminology correctly (Obj. 3.1 and 3.2)
Content: Introduction Project  Program  Portfolio selection Project life cycles and initiation Planning (Scope  Time  Cost  Stakeholder  Resources  Risk  Quality  Communication  Procurement) – both predictive and agile (and hybrid) Executing projects Monitoring and controlling  Closing Projects
Description: Over the past few years  emerging technology  new approaches  and rapid market changes disrupted our ways of working  driving the project management profession to evolve. Each industry  organization and project face unique challenges  and team members must adapt their approaches to successfully manage projects and deliver results. This course takes a deeper look into the fundamental concepts and constructs of project management. The course prepares the BIT students to apply their project management knowledge during their Practical Project in the final year of the program.
Judgement: ?Students ...… will be able to identify project relevant factors and judge their influence on project performance… can judge which life cycle to apply to a specific project… can tailor the tools and techniques to a specific project (Obj. 2.2)
Knowledge: ?Students ...… understand the project management principles and performance domains... understand project management terminology  tools  and techniques
Recommended Reading: Schwalbe  Kathy (2021): Introduction to Project Management ?PMI (2021): A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK Guide)  seventh edition
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Die Studierendenkönnen einen anregenden  überzeugenden fachlichen Beitrag in mündlicher Form leisten  können anspruchsvolle Texte inhaltlich korrekt und adressatengerecht mündlich wiedergeben.
Content: Inhalte Modulteil Wirtschaftskommunikation DE 2 Präsentationstechnik und Medien wirkungsvoll einsetzen Inhalte zielgruppengerecht visualisieren überzeugend verbal  nonverbal und paraverbal kommunizieren (Grundlagen in diesem Modul  Ergänzung dazu in Englisch) Redesorten kennen und anwenden Inhalte strukturieren und den Dialog mit dem Publikum dramaturgisch gestalten rhetorische Mittel wirkungsvoll einsetzen argumentieren und überzeugen Reden und Präsentationen analysieren und bewerten Stärken und Schwächen im eigenen Auftritt reflektieren konstruktiv Feedback geben und entgegennehmen  Inhalte Modulteil Wirtschaftskommunikation EN 2 Preparing and delivering effective business presentations Language and structuring of presentations: introducing  sequencing  summarising  interacting (Q and A)  Tailoring presentation to international audience Listening comprehension: Listening for gist and detail  vocabulary development  Business grammarBusiness vocabulary (Management/Operations including Financial reports)
Description: Sicher und überzeugend auftreten - Betriebsökonominnen und Betriebsökonomen müssen im Geschäftsalltag im Zweiergespräch  in Sitzungen oder Präsentationen ihre fachliche Kompetenz nutzen und vermitteln können. Vor einem wechselnden Publikum treten sie selbstsicher auf und vertreten ihre eigenen Gedanken und Positionen zu Fachthemen auch in der Diskussion überzeugend. In diesem Modul lernen die Studierenden eigene und fremde Gedanken verständlich  nachvollziehbar und sprachlich korrekt mündlich zu vermitteln. Sie erweitern ihr Vokabular  um sich im Geschäftsalltag kompetent auszudrücken. Die Studierenden erkennen ihre Stärken und Verbesserungspotenziale in ihrem mündlichen Ausdruck und Auftritt. Sie wissen  wie sie beides verbessern können.
Judgement: ?Die Studierendenkönnen die Qualität mündlicher Kommunikation anhand fundierter Kriterien beurteilen können ihr Urteil zur Qualität mündlicher Kommunikation begründen können die Relevanz von Informationen für ihre mündlichen Beiträge bewerten und eine begründete Auswahl treffen.
Knowledge: ?Die Studierenden kennen die wesentlichen Kriterien für einen prägnanten  überzeugenden mündlichen Auftritt und in der mündlichen Kommunikation (z. B. als Sitzungsleiter/innen) erweitern ihr Vokabular.
Recommended Reading: ?Wirtschaftskommunikation EN: Emmerson  P. (2009). Business Vocabulary Builder. Oxford: Macmillan Education.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: ? Die Studierendenkönnen ihre ökonomischen Erkenntnisse  Bedenken etc. einfach und klar schriftlich wie mündlich kommunizieren.
Content: Grundlagen der Volkswirtschaftslehre (Einführung  Markt und Staat  ökonomische Grundprinzipien)|  Allgemeine Entscheidungssituationen lösen mit Methoden wie Nutzwertanalyse  Opportunitätskostenvergleiche  Min-Max-Analyse  oder Wirtschaftlichkeitsanalysen  Marktmodelle der vollkommenen Konkurrenz wie auch unvollkommener Konkurrenz - insbesondere bei Informationsgütern. Staatliche Regulierung und Marktinterventionen  um Marktteilnehmer zu schützen und Marktversagen zu lindern   Messen makroökonomischer Grössen wie BIP  Inflation  Arbeitslosigkeit  etc. Das Magische Sechseck makroökonomischer Ziele Wachstumspolitik und Unternehmenswachstum  Geld und Geldpolitik  die sowohl die Preise wie die Gesamtproduktion beeinflussen   Staatliche Finanzen und Fiskalpolitik  u.a. um Konjunkturausschläge zu mildern Aussenwirtschaftliche Zusammenhänge und unternehmerische Opportunitäten
Description: Mikroökonomie analysiert und erklärt  wie wir als Personen aber auch die Firmen wirtschaften und rationale Entscheide fällen. Makroökonomie zeigt auf  wie eine gesamte Wirtschaft funktioniert. Verantwortungsbewusste Führungspersonen benötigen (mikroökonomische) Entscheidungstechniken und oft auch einen gesamtwirtschaftlichen (makroökonomischen) Überblick.
Judgement: Die Studierendenkönnen individuelle wie unternehmerische Entscheidungssituationen skizzieren  Vorschläge aufzeigen und verschiedene Varianten beurteilen bzw. optimal entscheiden/auswählen.      E 4.2                 können gesamtwirtschaftliche Fragestellungen über Geld- und Fiskalpolitik wie auch Aussenwirtschaftsfragen strukturieren  interpretieren und beurteilen.
Knowledge: Die Studierendenkennen verschiedene Märkte mit unterschiedlichen Marktstrukturen und die zu erwartenden Marktgleichgewichte.kennen Faktormärkte wie auch gesamtwirtschaftliche Zusammenhänge.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Module Name: Zeitgeschichte in Berlin: Zeitzeugen erzählen von der DDR-Planwirtschaft
Communication: Die Studierenden - können sich auf den jeweiligen »Zeitzeugen» einstellen  seine Schwerpunkte und die Subjektivität seiner Sichtweise erkennen.   - können nachfragen und in einen Dialog mit den «Zeitzeu-gen» treten. - können formales Basiswissen und persönliche Erzählung gedanklich verbinden.
Content: ?Im Zentrum der drei Kurstage in Berlin stehen Begegnungen mit Zeitzeugen: enteigneten Bauern  Stahlarbeitern  Wirtschaftsplanern  Kombinatsleitern und Wissenschaftlern. Sie erzählen von ihren Erfahrungen in der DDR-Wirtschaft.
Description: Mit der Finanzkrise kamen die sozialistischen Gesellschaftsmodelle wieder ins Gespräch. Eine gerechtere Wirtschaftsordnung sollte das Fundamten für eine gerechtere Gesellschaft bilden. Aber Theorie und Praxis fielen auseinander. Im Ostblock war die DDR der wirtschaftlich leistungsstärkste Staat. Dennoch brach dessen Ökonomie nach 40 Jahren zusammen. Anhand dieses Landes lassen sich modellartig die Einführung der Planwirtschaft  ihre Probleme in der Praxis und die Schwierigkeiten im Übergang zur Marktwirtschaft gut zeigen.  Im Zentrum der drei Kurstage in Berlin stehen Begegnungen mit Zeitzeugen: enteigneten Bauern  Stahlarbeitern  Wirtschaftsplanern  Kombinatsleitern und Wissenschaftlern. Sie erzählen von ihren Erfahrungen in der DDR-Wirtschaft.
Judgement: Die Studierenden - können die Nachteile und Schwierigkeiten der Planwirt-schaft benennen - können den Zusammenhang von Demokratie und Wirt-schaftsentwicklung beschreiben. - können die Relevanz von verschiedenen Faktoren für nati-onale Entwicklungen benennen. - erkennen den Zusammenhang von Biographie und Welt-sicht.
Knowledge: Die Studierenden - kennen die historische Gesamtentwicklung der DDR. - kennen Grundelemente sozialistischer Gesellschaften. - kennen das Modell der Planwirtschaft.  - kennen die Merkmale von Diktaturen. - Kennen die Problem beim Übergang in die Marktwirtschaft.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: ?Die Studierenden ... ... führen ein Projekt zum Erfolg  halten dabei die Auftraggeberschaft jederzeit und transparent auf dem Laufenden und vermitteln den generierten Mehrwert personenspezifisch. ... sind in der Lage  eigene Arbeitsergebnisse für eine bestimmte Zielgruppe in mündlicher Form verständlich und überzeugend darzustellen. ... sind in der Lage  eigene Arbeitsergebnisse für eine bestimmte Zielgruppe in schriftlicher Form verständlich und überzeugend darzustellen.
Content: ?vom Projektauftrag zum Projektziel Projektrisiken / Qualitätssicherung Projektorganisation Planung  Steuerung und Überwachung Methoden / Tools in der täglichen Projektarbeit soziale Kompetenz in Projekten Konfliktmanagement
Description: ?Das Praxisprojekt ist die Anwendung der Inhalte aus dem Modul "Projektmanagement". Die Studenten haben für ein Unternehmen bzw. eine Organisation in einem definierten Zeitrahmen mit einem definierten Budget einen definierten Mehrwert zu generieren.
Judgement: ?Die Studierenden ... ... bewerten unternehmerische Probleme  die ein Projekt begründen könnten  und schätzen diese auf deren operationale Lösbarkeit hin ein. ... sind in der Lage  die Funktionalitäten und Einsatzmöglichkeiten bestehender Standardanwendungen zu analysieren und deren potenziellen Nutzen für verschiedene Einsatzfelder im Unternehmen zu beurteilen. ... sind in der Lage  Informationen über aktuelle IT-Trends selbständig aufzufinden  auszuwerten und deren Bedeutung für die Anwendung in Organisationen kritisch einzuschätzen.
Knowledge: ?Die Studierenden ... ... bewältigen die Probleme und Wechselbeziehungen im Managen komplexer Projekte der Wirtschaftsinformatik und Wirtschaft. ... verstehen implizit die Modellierung und Optimierung von Geschäftsprozessen.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: ?Students learn to argue and present working with their group work         can present their own results for a specific target group in an understandable and convincing oral form (Obj. 3.2)
Content: Strategic Management and IT Strategy ImplicationsIT Strategy Analysis: Alignment with BusinessInnovation with IT TechnologyExploiting Information Systems for Strategic AdvantageDetermine and defining Business Information Systems StrategyManaging the Portfolio of Business ApplicationsFinancial Aspects: Justifying and Managing Information SystemsOrganizational Aspects: A Framework for Managing Information SystemsStrategic Management of IT Services and IT Infrastructure
Description: ? In the course of digital transformation  IT is developing from service provider to business enabler or even business driver. In this way  a well-functioning IT management is essential as the backbone of IT control and planning. This is the only way for companies to secure their position in the long term.
Judgement: ?Students can analyze IT trends and define corresponding strategies (Obj. 4.1). can judge working with the case study but also in the discussion of cases of other companies  which are taken as examples:which method/procedure is suitable for which initial situationthe advantages and risks associated with itcan analyze available company-wide information about the current situation in the company  (Obj. 4.2).
Knowledge: ?  Students acquire sound knowledge of methods and tools for the strategic and operational areas of IT management such asIT Strategy and Alignment with Business  Strategy IT management from a tactical and operational point of viewIT organization and managementTransformation and Innovation Students can model and optimize IT management processes (Obj. 1.1)
Title: Module Description

Programme: BSc. Betriebsökonomie |BSc. Wirtschaftsinformatik |BSc. Business Information Technology |BSc. Business Administration |
Communication: ?Die Studierendenkönnen sich auf den jeweiligen Gast/»Zeitzeugen» einstellen  seine Schwerpunkte und die Subjektivität seiner Sichtweise erkennen.können nachfragen und in einen Dialog mit den «Zeitzeugen» treten. können formales Basiswissen und persönliche Erzählung gedanklich verbinden
Content: ?Berichte von Zeitzeugen  Journalisten und Wissenschaftlern. Es handelt sich dabei um Länder Osteuropas wie die Ukraine  Rumänien  Polen  das ehemalige Jugoslawien oder Ungarn. Eingangs wird ein Überblick über die europäische Geschichte des 20. Jahrhunderts gegeben
Description: ?Das Europa des 21. Jahrhunderts ist zu einem großen Zukunftsthema geworden  aber die Geschichte und Probleme der einzelnen Länder gehören nicht zum Allgemeinwissen. Das gilt besonders für Osteuropa. Dabei hat sich mit dem Zusammenbruch des Ostblocks Europa neu geordnet  völlig neuartige und mächtige Reise-  Handels- und Migrationsströme haben sich herausgebildet  die das westliche Europa mit der östlichen Welt vieler Völker  Sprachen  Kulturen und Konfessionen konfrontiert  mit einem Europa vor der Planierung und Provinzialisierung durch Nationalsozialismus und Kommunismus. Anhand der Geschichte und Situation einzelner osteuropäischer Länder soll der Blick auf das geistige Fundamt der europäischen Idee geschärft und das Bewusstsein für die Herausforderungen und Möglichkeiten eines Europas von morgen geweckt werden.
Judgement: Die Studierendenkönnen den Stand von Demokratie und Wirtschaftsentwicklung beschreibenkönnen die Relevanz von verschiedenen Faktoren für nationale Entwicklungen benennen
Knowledge: ?Die Studierendenkennen die historische Gesamtentwicklung Osteuropas und der Sowjetunionkennen geographische und historische Fakten zur den behandelten Nationenkennen das Model der Planwirtschaft kennen die Merkmale von Diktaturen
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: The students can communicate economic sutuations and relationsships in an understandable way and an easy language
Content: Fundamentals of economics (introduction with basic economic principles  markets and state) Solving general decision situations with methods such as utility value analysis  opportunity cost comparison  min-max analysis  or profitability analysis Market models of perfect competition as well as imperfect competition  especially for information goods. Public goods  government regulation and market intervention to protect market participants and alleviate market failures Measuring macroeconomic variables such as GDP  inflation  unemployment  etc. The magic hexagon of macroeconomic objectives Growth policy and corporate growth Money  monetary policy  prices and total output Government finances  fiscal policy  economic fluctuations and corporate risks Foreign economic relationships and entrepreneurial opportunities
Description: ?Microeconomics analyses and explains how we as individuals  but also as companies  operate and make rational decisions. Macroeconomics shows how an entire economy functions. Responsible managers need (microeconomic) decision-making techniques and often a macroeconomic overview.
Judgement: The students - can make optimal decisions in various market situations as consumers  workers as well as entrepreneurs. E  4.2 - can interpret market interventions (taxes  subsidies  price and quantity targets) in terms of their main and side effects as well as their efficiency. - can show macroeconomic causal chains (causes and consequences).
Knowledge: ?the students - know different markets (goods/services) with different market structures and the expected market equilibria. - know factor markets as well as macroeconomic relationships.
Title: Module Description

Programme: BSc. Betriebsökonomie |BSc. Business Administration |BSc. International Business Management |
Communication: Präsentationen zum Seminarthema.Aktive Beteiligung am Thema.
Content: Ökonomische WachstumsmodelleWohlfahrts- und Wohlstandsbegriff der ÖkonomiePhilosophische Konzepte von Reichtum und Gelungenem LebenKonzepte der Degrowth- und Postwachstumsökonomie
Description: Muss die Wirtschaft immer weiterwachsen und was bedeutet ein solcher Zwang für die Menschen  für die Natur und letztlich für die Kultur insgesamt? Welche Qualitäten kämen demgegenüber zum Tragen  wenn die Wirtschaft nicht mehr auf Wachstum setzen würde. In diesem Seminar diskutieren wir Möglichkeiten  aber auch Schwierigkeiten einer wachstumsfreien Wirtschaft  wobei wir Positionen aus der Philosophie und der Ökonomie miteinander ins Gespräch bringen wollen.
Judgement: Die Studierendensind mit der Kritik am wirtschaftlichen Wachstumsmodell vertraut.können Entwürfe der Wachstumskritik beurteilen.können die Idee der Postwachstumsgesellschaft kritisch hinterfragen.
Knowledge: Die Studierendenkennen die Wachstumstreiber der Wirtschaft.kennen den geschichtlichen Hintergrund des heute weltweit dominierenden auf Wachstum ausgerichteten Wirtschaftssystems.verstehen  wie Wachstum des BIP und Gewinne der Unternehmen zusammenhängen.können die Auswirkungen einer grenzenlos wachsenden Wirtschaft nachvollziehen.sind in der Lage  Alternativen zu der herrschenden Wachstumsideologie aus philosophischen Quellen entwickeln.sind in der Lage  Alternativen zum herrschenden Wachstumsmodell aus ökonomischen und volkswirtschaftlichen Positionen zu beurteilen.kennen Hauptpositionen der Postwachstumsökonomie.
Recommended Reading: ?Posted in moodle
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Module Name: Integration Module_Digital Banking Management Game  vOlten
Communication: Work productively in diverse groups composed of students of different cultures  ethnic groups and genders (Obj. 4.1)Communicate effectively through business reports (Obj. 3.1)
Content: Problem analyzing and solution finding in different areas of the banking business during several simulation periods: Business BankingInvestment BankingWealth ManagementMarketingHuman Resources / LogisticsFinancial Management / Treasury Digitalization  The different areas of business can be activated and customized to the specific needs and backgrounds of the class. Several teams (3 to 5 students) build the management of different banks in a country. You will have to analyse the starting situation  and  based on further infor-mation  make decisions in managing your bank for each simulation period (4-6 periods) in a competitive environment. The goal for each team is to represent the 'best' managed bank.  The simulation is cloud-based.
Description: In t?his Digital Banking – cloud-based banking simulation game students will participate in a digital banking simulation and will experience the challenges of designing and implementing strategies in a dynamic competitive market. Problem analyzing and solution finding in different areas of the banking business during several simulation periods: Business Banking  Investment Banking  Wealth Management  Marketing  Human Resources / Logistics  Financial Management / Treasury  Digitalization.  The goal for each team is to represent the 'best' managed bank.
Judgement: ?make decisions and lead the different divisions within a bank in a near-realistic competitive environment (Obj. 2.1)evaluate and determine digitalization strategies and goals in a competitive environment (Obj. 2.1) manage difficult and complex decisions even in periods of uncertainty (Obj. 2.1)
Knowledge: ?explain banking economic and entrepreneurial relationships (Obj. 1.1) identify and understand the interdependencies and correlations between the different business units of a bank (Obj. 1.1) explain essential factors which contribute to a success of a bank (Obj. 1.1)explain the relationships between different aspects in a financial institution (Obj. 1.1) improve their networked thinking and acting abilities (Obj. 1.1) understand the fundamental principles of Basel III (Obj. 1.1)
Title: Module Description

Communication: Die Studierendenverwenden korrektes Fachvokabular für schriftliche und mündliche Kommunikation. sind für die Besonderheiten der unternehmensübergreifenden  (teil-)automatisierten Zusammenarbeit in Netzwerken sensibilisiert.
Content: Die grundlegenden Begriffe  Definitionen und Konzepte im Kontext von Supply Chain Management und Logistik  Digital Business sowie Sustainability.Die Teilfunktionen und Akteure des Supply Chain Managements und ihren Wertbeitrag in der wirtschaftlichen Erfüllung der Kundenbedürfnisse (Einkauf  Produktion  Lagerhaltung  Distribution  Transport).Die Waren-  Informations-  Dokumenten-  und Finanzflüsse sowie die kommerziellen und rechtlichen Beziehungen im Supply Chain Management.Die Funktionsweisen und Erfolgsfaktoren der digital vernetzten Wertschöpfung.Die Rolle von Technologie und Infrastruktur in der digital vernetzten Wertschöpfung.Mit vernetzter Informationstechnologie unterstützte Geschäftsmodelle (E-Commerce  Marktplätze  virtuelle Wertschöpfung  Disintermediation und Disruption).Supply Chain Management in traditionellen und digitalen Geschäftsmodellen (Beziehungsmanagement  Management von Wertschöpfungsnetzwerken und Ökosystemen  Kollaborative Innovation und Supply Chain-Analytik)Methoden und Instrumente zur Messung und Erreichung von ökologischen  wirtschaftlichen und sozialen Zielen in der vernetzten Wertschöpfung.
Description: Vernetzung und Nachhaltigkeit sind die kritischen Erfolgsfaktoren des 21. Jahrhunderts. Unternehmen erwarten von der neuen Generation an Betriebsökonominnen und Betriebsökonomen  dass sie das Verständnis und das grundlegende Rüstzeug mitbringen  um Wertschöpfung kundenfokussiert  vernetzt und nachhaltig gestalten zu können.   Sie müssen daher erkennen  wie diese Erfolgsfaktoren im globalen Wettbewerb wirken und von Unternehmen erfolgreich eingesetzt werden können. Sie müssen verstehen  wie digitale Vernetzung Märkte verändert (Digital Business)  wie physische und digitale Wertschöpfung zusammenwachsen (Supply Chain Management) und wo in diesen Entwicklungen Innovationspotenzial entsteht – im Hinblick auf Ökonomie  Ökologie und Gesellschaft (Sustainability).   In diesem Modul erlernen Sie die grundlegenden Begriffe  Konzepte  Methoden und Instrumente  mit denen Sie die vernetzte Wirtschaft des 21. Jahrhunderts nachhaltig gestalten können.
Follow up module: Die Inhalte dieses Moduls sind mit den Inhalten der Studienrichtung «Digital Business and Value Networks» abgestimmt.
Judgement: Die Studierendenkönnen die Auswirkungen der vernetzten Wertschöpfung auf Unternehmen  Gesellschaft und Umwelt beurteilen.können unternehmensübergreifende Wertschöpfung in Bezug auf Ökonomie  Ökologie und Gesellschaft beurteilen.können Geschäftsmodelle auf deren Eignung für die digital vernetzte Wirtschaft und Gesellschaft beurteilen.können mit Supply Chain Management  Digital Business und Sustainability verbundene Innovationspotentiale bewerten.
Knowledge: Die Studierendenverstehen die Chancen  Kunden in der digitalen Zukunft schneller mit immer passgenaueren Angeboten zu gewinnen und zu halten.verstehen die Herausforderungen  denen Unternehmen in einer digital und physisch vernetzten Welt gegenüberstehen.verstehen die Veränderungen  die durch die globale und digitale Vernetzung der Wirtschaft ausgelöst werden.verstehen die Bedeutung und Elemente von Nachhaltigkeit in der global vernetzten Wertschöpfung.verstehen die grundlegenden Konzepte  Methoden und Instrumente der unternehmensübergreifenden Wertschöpfung mittels Supply Chain Management und Digital Business.kennen die Grundlagen  Voraussetzungen und Funktionsweisen digitaler und vernetzter Geschäftsmodelle.verstehen den Stellenwert von digitaler und physischer Infrastruktur und von Technologien im Kontext der Vernetzung.verstehen die Auswirkungen des eigenen Handelns in einer digital und physisch vernetzten Welt.
Recommended Reading: Die Kernliteratur wird auf Moodle zur Verfügung gestellt.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Module Name: Integration Module_Digital Banking Management Game  vBrugg-Windisch
Communication: ? Work productively in diverse groups composed of students of different cultures  ethnic groups and genders (Obj. 4.1)Communicate effectively through business reports (Obj. 3.1)
Content: ?Problem analyzing and solution finding in different areas of the banking business during several simulation periods: Business BankingInvestment BankingWealth ManagementMarketingHuman Resources / LogisticsFinancial Management / Treasury Digitalization  The different areas of business can be activated and customized to the specific needs and backgrounds of the class. Several teams (3 to 5 students) build the management of different banks in a country. You will have to analyse the starting situation  and  based on further infor-mation  make decisions in managing your bank for each simulation period (4-6 periods) in a competitive environment. The goal for each team is to represent the 'best' managed bank.  The simulation is cloud-based.
Description: In this Digital Banking – cloud-based banking simulation game students will participate in a digital banking simulation and will experience the challenges of designing and implementing strategies in a dynamic competitive market. Problem analyzing and solution finding in different areas of the banking business during several simulation periods: Business Banking  Investment Banking  Wealth Management  Marketing  Human Resources / Logistics  Financial Management / Treasury  Digitalization.   The goal for each team is to represent the 'best' managed bank.
Judgement: ?make decisions and lead the different divisions within a bank in a near-realistic competitive environment (Obj. 2.1)evaluate and determine digitalization strategies and goals in a competitive environment (Obj. 2.1)                                                        manage difficult and complex decisions even in periods of uncertainty                          (Obj. 2.1)
Knowledge: ?explain banking economic and entrepreneurial relationships (Obj. 1.1) identify and understand the interdependencies and correlations between the different business units of a bank (Obj. 1.1) explain essential factors which contribute to a success of a bank (Obj. 1.1)explain the relationships between  different aspects in a financial institution (Obj. 1.1) improve their networked thinking and acting abilities (Obj. 1.1) understand the fundamental principles of Basel III (Obj. 1.1)
Title: Module Description

Programme: BSc. Betriebsökonomie |BSc. Business Administration |BSc. Wirtschaftsinformatik |BSc. Business Information Technology |
Communication: Die Studierendenkennen die relevanten Fachbegriffe des betrieblichen Risikomanagements und wenden diese treffend an.kennen die relevanten Fachbegriffe im Bereich der Unternehmensversicherung und wenden diese treffend an.bereiten multimedial unterstützte Präsentationen zu einem Fachthema vor und führen diese durch.
Content: Grundlagen  Begriffe und Definitionen des RisikomanagementsGesetzliche Rahmenbedingungen  Prozesse  Methoden  Tools etc. des RisikomanagementsRisiken erkennen  Analyse  Bewertung  Bewältigung  Überwachung von unternehmensexternen und -internen Risikofelder und –faktorenVerantwortlichkeiten und OrganisationRisikomanagement im Kontext der Unternehmensführung (Corporate Governance) und des strategischen ManagementsUmgang mit Betrugsrisiken (Fraud)Digital Security und Risikomanagement im Kontext des digitalen WandelsFallstudie zum Risikomanagement im SpitalEinführung und Definition von Grundprinzipien der UnternehmensversicherungVersicherbarkeit von RisikenPreisbildung bei VersicherungsproduktenVorstellung von ausgewählten Produkten im Bereich der UnternehmensversicherungDiskussion und kritische Betrachtung der Einsatzmöglichkeiten  Wirksamkeit und Grenzen von ausgewählten Produkten im Bereich der Unternehmensversicherung
Description: In einer von hoher Dynamik geprägten Geschäftswelt sehen sich Unternehmen zahlreichen strategischen  operationellen  finanziellen und reputationsmässigen Risiken gegenüber  welche sich darüber hinaus schnell bilden und verändern. Diese für das Gesamtunternehmen holistisch zu identifizieren  analysieren  bewerten und handhaben ist Aufgabe des betrieblichen Risikomanagements und gehört zu den zentralen Aufgaben einer wirksamen Unternehmenssteuerung und -überwachung (Corporate Governance). Zur Bewältigung und Auslagerung von Risiken sind Versicherungen ein wichtiger Partner. Teilweise ermöglicht die Auslagerung von Risiken mittels Versicherungslösungen überhaupt erst die Ausübung einer Geschäftstätigkeit. Denn ohne Risiken eingehen zu können  kann ein Unternehmen auch kaum Chancen nutzen. Dieses Fachmodul beleuchtet daher das Risikomanagement als Führungsaufgabe aus Sicht der Unternehmen und die Rolle von Versicherungen für Unternehmen  um zukünftigen Fach- und Führungskräften relevante Grundlagen für das Treffen von Entscheidungen und das Übernehmen von Verantwortung zu bieten.   Hinweis: In diesem Fachmodul geht es um das betriebliche Risikomanagement und Versicherungslösungen als übergreifenden Prozess. Der Fokus liegt ausdrücklich nicht auf Teildisziplinen wie dem finanziellen bzw. quantitativen Risikomanagement.
Judgement: Die Studierendenbeurteilen beispielhafte Sachverhalte und Situationen unter Anwendung von Methoden und Tools des betrieblichen Risikomanagements.beurteilen Arten der Risikoübertragung an Versicherungen in beispielhaften Situationen.reflektieren die Lerninhalte des Moduls und deren Wirksamkeit in beispielhaften betrieblichen Kontexten kritisch.
Knowledge: Die Studierendenkennen die Definition und Bedeutung des betrieblichen Risikomanagements.kennen die Methoden und Tools des betrieblichen Risikomanagements.kennen die Definition  Rolle und Bedeutung von Versicherungen für Unternehmen.kennen die grundlegenden Prinzipien und Funktionsweisen von Versicherungen.kennen ausgewählte Versicherungsprodukte  welche für Unternehmen relevant sind.
Recommended Reading: ?Mahnke  A.  & Rohlfs  T. (Hrsg.). (2020). Betriebliches Risikomanagement und Industrieversicherung: Erfolgreiche Unternehmenssteuerung durch ein effektives Risiko- und Versicherungsmanagement. Springer Fachmedien. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-658-30421-8

The Communication Teams' work is split across and credited with two modules: Business Communication 4 and this Integration Module.

Communication: Present written and oral arguments in a convincing manner (Obj. 3.2)  Organize a group case study and demonstrate the ability to work as a team
Content: Introduction Global challenges and sustainable developmentSustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and their interconnectivity  The role  potential and state of innovationExplanation of the course assignment and group formation       The Sustainable Innovation Canvas In-depth explanation of the tool Introduction to additional tools such as i.e. root-cause-analysis or value proposition Case studies Introduction to 5 innovation cases (intra- and entrepreneurship) Excursion(s) to further explore an innovation case Interview sessions with the entrepreneurs Analysis of the innovation case in groups using the Sustainable Innvoation Canvas        Impact measurement          Theory of changeThe importance and practice of evaluationPractical info to get started Legal framework and ecosystem in Switzerland Further FHNW and ecosystem opportunities
Description: The course aims to encourage students to explore the economic  environmental  and social impacts of human consumption and to examine possible innovative solutions through sustainable entrepreneurship. The acquired knowledge and skills prepare the students for a business world in which innovation and entrepreneurship will become more and more important – especially in the context of substantial topics like climate change mitigation  circular economy  reducing inequality and fighting poverty  malnutrition and illiteracy. Through a case-study-based teaching model  students will be able to put themselves in the shoes of social and sustainable entrepreneurs and analyze the presented business models based on guiding tools. Furthermore  students will also gain real insights into the hopes  struggles and motivation of entrepreneurs for sustainable development and maybe get inspired to become one themselves.
Judgement: ?Assess innovative business  marketing and communication strategies for socially and environmentally responsible products and services in a sharing economy (Obj. 2.1) Evaluate and justify the application of innovative sustainable entrepreneurship strategies (Obj. 2.1)
Knowledge: Acquire solid knowledge of fundamental theory          behind modern concepts of sustainable          development  corporate sustainability  sustainable          entrepreneurship and innovationIdentify key topical issues and aspects of sustainable development that offers sustainable entrepreneurs the chance to develop innovative solutions and business models (focus on consumer goods and food)
Recommended Reading: Selected texts - see Moodle
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students ... use correct technical vocabulary for written and oral communication. are aware of the particularities of cross-company and (partially) automated collaboration in networks.
Content: The fundamental terms  definitions and concepts of Supply Chain Management & LogisticsThe partial functions and actors of Supply Chain Management & Logistics and their value contribution to the fulfilment of customer needs (purchasing  production  warehousing  distribution  transport). Key aspects of Supply Chain Design and Management (customer and supplier relationship management  management of value networks and ecosystems  collaborative innovation and supply chain analytics) The flows of goods  information  documents  values as well as financial flows and legal issues in Supply Chain Management & LogisticsThe functioning and the success factors of digitally networked value creation. The role of technology and infrastructure in digitally networked value creation. Methods and tools for measuring and achieving ecological  economic and social goals in networked value creation.
Description: Co-creating value in networks is key to 21st century business success. Companies expect business information technology students to be aware of this  and that they are equipped with the right toolbox to create value in a customer-centric  networked and sustainable way. As a student  you must understand the workings of these success factors and their interplay with business information technology. That means understanding how connectivity and physical and digital value creation can be combined  and where innovation potential arises in this development: economically  ecologically  and socially. In this module  you will learn about the basic terms  concepts  methods and tools of Supply Chain Management & Logistics that will help you shape the networked economy of the 21st century in a sustainable way.
Judgement: ?Students ... can assess the impact of networked value creation on companies  society and the environment. can assess cross-company value creation in terms of economy  ecology and society. can assess innovation potentials associated with Supply Chain Management & Logistics technology.
Knowledge: ?Students ... understand the basic concepts  methods and instruments of cross-company value creation through Supply Chain Management. understand how to win customers faster and keep them longer in a digital future with ever more specialized offers. understand the challenges that companies face in a digitally and physically networked world. understand the changes triggered by global and digital connectivity and networks.understand the importance and aspects of sustainability in globally networked value creation. know the fundamentals  prerequisites and functioning of networked value co-creation. understand the importance of digital and physical infrastructure and technologies in the context of networked value-creation. understand the effects of their own actions in a networked world.
Recommended Reading: Key readings are available via Moodle.
Title: Module Description

Communication: Students ...?be able to propose and defend one's own approach to solving a given problem (in the bonus point task)
Content: Types of information objects and their characteristicsAnalysis of business processes for prediction of information needsStrategies for manual knowledge organizationPreprocessing and indexing of textSearch facets  meta data  meta data standards  encoding schemesAutomatic extraction of metadata (information extraction  classification)Information retrieval models and ranking functions (Boolean retrieval  vector space model)Evaluation criteria  procedures and measures for information retrieval systemsKnowledge organization and retrieval strategies for semi-structures information (email  social media  …)Information management requirementsDMS and ECM systems overviewInformation governance and legal aspectsData and Metadata managementFunctional components of ECM systemsProducts and product categoriesDMS & ECM rollout and strategy
Description: ?ECM looks at the management of structured and unstructured information from a strategic viewpoint  based on the needs of knowledge workers. In the module  the focus is set first on identifying the needs of knowledge workers along a company's core business processes. Then  suitable tools and methods are discussed to support the retrieval  (collaborative) creation  use  archiving and deleltion of documents to fulfil these needs.
Judgement: Students ...?analyse business processes and predict corresponding information needs (Objective 1.2)                 analyse  judge and compare the merits of different information management solutions            (Objective 2.1)                          orchestrate systems according to a given situation                  (Objective 2.1)
Knowledge: Students ...?illustrate the different types of information objects                distinguish the functionality of different tool categories                explain how to support collaboration within and across teams (access rights  transparency and closed user groups  workflows vs. document management  versioning  publishing  document categories)                illustrate architecture (layers and tiers) and governance (roles and responsibilities  re-organisation lifecycle) of ECM systems                explain the legal aspects (archiving  compliance standards  security issues)                 describe potential and limitations of automatic metadata extraction for text + potential applications for multimedia
Recommended Reading: Christopher D. Manning  Prabhakar Raghavan and Hinrich Schütze Introduction to Information Retrieval  Cambridge University Press. 2008. The course focuses on current and future developments as well as their impact on companies/organizations.

Content: Corporate strategy:Aspects of the overall management of a businessCorporate management in a strategic contextStrategic positioningEnvironmental and corporate analysisStrategy development and implementationManagement of organizational change      Business Simulation:Strategic and operative planningPerformance measurement and managementSales and marketing: market analysis  profit-contribution-margin analysis as informational basis for marketing decisionsManufacturing: investment and outsourcing decisions  utilization planningResearch & development: strategies for product improvementsHuman resources: requirements analysis and personnel adjustmentFinancial policy  financial balance in financing and liquidity
Description: This course provides up-to-date information on strategic management and business simulation. It helps students to develop  evalute and implement strategies as well as explore desion-making issues in a simulated business environment.
Judgement: They can work towards targets in a realistic economic environment with complex decision-making situations using economic management instruments in a target-oriented manner
Knowledge: ?They can describe and give examples of what strategic planning and strategic management is and are familiar with the most important components of the strategy process. They have experienced a business context and the complexity of its dynamics and are able to describe and give examples how business is affected by its environments
Recommended Reading: Grant  R.M. (2016). Contemporary Strategy Analysis: Text and Cases.9th Edition  TJ International  Padstow  Cornwall  GB: Wiley.Peppard  J. and J. Ward (2016). The Strategic Management of Information Systems: building a digital strategy. 4th Edition  TJ International  UK: Wiley.
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students...  ... can correctly interpret the results and insights of a data analytics and data mining tool and communicate them in an understandable way.    ... are able to explain a decision system modeled in ADAPT.
Content: Decision support with data warehousing Methods of Data Warehousing: Data Warehouse Architectures Data modeling with ADAPT and star schema Data Selection and Transformation Development and operation of a DWH OLAP  Data Mining Processes and Tasks classification method clustering process association algorithms
Description: In the first part of the module  basic data mining technologies for decision support are discussed and tested on a software tool. In particular  we discuss the classification and clustering of data objects as well as association analysis.    In the second part of the module  the necessary infrastructure for data-based decision support in companies is explained. In particular  the components necessary for setting up and operating a data warehouse are covered.
Judgement: ?Students...  ... can assign a given use case to a suitable data mining algorithm (or assess whether data mining is useful at all or not) (Obj. 2.1)    ... can judge whether a system is overtrained or well generalized.    ... can correctly interpret a certain result of a clustering/classification/association analysis (e.g. the Precision  the Dunn Index or the Confidence as one respective example).    ... can judge a reporting system on the basis of the SUCCESS rules
Knowledge: ?Students... ... can define data mining comprehensively and distinguish it from related areas. ... know the differences between classification and clustering as well as between supervised and unsupervised learning. ... can enumerate and distinguish the different types of features. ... know how to basically learn from data (e.g. via cross validation). ... know the differences of the different clustering types (e.g. Hard vs. Fuzzy) ... know the basic difficulties of naïve methods (brute force) in data mining ... know the components necessary for a decision-supporting infrastructure
Title: Module Description

Communication: Students ... (3.2  4.2) recognize and overcome barriers to successful interpersonal communicationrecognize the importance of cultural sensitivity in the workplace
Content: Various models and approaches to interpersonal and intercultural communication such as:Online communication Psychology of Communication Transactional models of communicationFace-saving/-threatening communication  politeness theory Barriers to effective interpersonal communication such as category-based perception  common social biases  causal attributionGroup communication  the group as a social system  group roles and norms  communicative group behavioursTeam formation  communication and cooperationImplicit and explicit styles of communicationConflict resolutionInterpersonal communication skillsIntercultural communicationConcept of cultureHofstede's cultural dimensions as a framework for intercultural communicationCultural dimensions by Edward T. Hall  Fons Trompenaars and Erin Meyer       NB. Models and approaches may differ depending on teaching location
Description: Employers are increasingly assessing current staff and future hires on how well they relate and communicate to others. Regardless of the position employees hold or of their job responsibilities  they need to be able to work well with their co-workers. This course helps students attune their communication to someone else's persepctive  assess and improve their own ability to communicate clearly and openly  listen and respond empathetically.
Judgement: Students ... (3.2) analyze the impact of perception and interpretation on communication and behavior in social interaction interact effectively and appropriately in inter-cultural situations to reach communication goals
Knowledge: Students ...explain how a communication exchange can go wrong and whyidentify the differences and similarities of cultures in terms of cultural indicators
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students ......communicate within the team  to coordinate the project work ...deliver documentation for the individual project phases (Obj. 3.1)
Content: The IT project is a group project  to implementa a complete software project. The project to be implemented is presented at the initial kickoff. The specific project is different in each semester  and is chosen so that it can be completed in the given time. The project includes multiple aspects of real software projects: user interfaces  multilingual capability  network communication  databases  data management  etc..   Based on a rough project description  the team must complete all phases of software project development: requirements  system design  implementation and testing. At the end  the team delivers working software as well as complete documentation. The internal organization of the team is left to the students. However  it is important that each student implements (programs) a portion of the code. This will be individually checked (oral exam on the student's own code) and is a requirement to pass the course.
Description: This is the capstone of the previous technical courses: Students gain practical experience in a larger software project. As part of a team  students begin with a rough project description  define the specific project requirements  develope the design  implement the code and test the finished application.   As in real software projects  the most important goal is to deliver working software. In order to pass the IT project  the team must deliver a project that fulfills the defined minimum requirements.
Judgement: ?Students ......plan the project in iterations| decide  which requirements belong to which iteration  so that the project can be successfully delivered ...makes decisions as requires - for example  if certain requirements cannot be implemented in the given time - so that the overal project remains successful
Knowledge: ?Students ......understand all phases of software development and implementation  as learned in earlier courses. This is supported by feedback from the instructor on the individual project phases.
Title: Module Description

Module Name: Focus: Special Topics in International Management
Communication: Present written and oral arguments in a convincing manner (Obj. 3.1| Obj. 4.1)Communicate with cultural sensitivity (Obj. 4.2)
Content: Part I: The context of international managementDrivers  benefits  and consequences of international businessesComparing differences between two markets (CAGE model)International ethics and social responsibilityPart II: The effect of culture on organization and management Working and living abroad: Culture shockThe organization of international businessOrganizational cultureGlobal work culturePart III: Culture-bound management practices Country-specific analysis: management of SMES in China  India  Russia  and Switzerland  Case studies on entry to foreign countries and challenges to achieve business goalsPart IV: Emerging topics on intercultural management Criss management across culturesManagement for innovation (diversity and team) Digital society  the future of labour force and organizations
Description: Module Description This module is designed to prepare students to meet management challenges in the international context. It is NOT focused on International Business but has rather a strong orientation toward cultural dimensions of international businesses  including managing self in a cross-cultural environment and multicultural workforce. This course applies a balanced and integrated approach to the subject  combing organization and management theories with cross border business case studies. Intensive discussions will be around the role of national culture in the international management. Several country-specific sessions will give students an in-depth understanding of strategic choice in conducting international business as well as organizational aspects to ensure the success of companies' international endeavour.
Judgement: Evaluate the external environment and internal resources for global outreach and identify implications (Obj. 2.1| Obj. 4.1)Assess various organizational culture and managers' conduction of international management and make recommendations (Obj. 2.1| Obj. 4.1)
Knowledge: Explain the broad context of international business  including the emerging trends impacting international management (Obj. 1.1)Explain the opportunities and advantages of entering and operating in foreign markets (Obj. 1.1| Obj. 4.1)Identify and explain the major challenges and issues related to the management across borders and cultures (Obj. 1.3| Obj. 4.1)Explain how corporate culture supports international operations (Obj. 1.1| Obj. 4.1)Anticipate culture-bound management practices (Obj. 1.1| Obj. 4.1).Explain and critically reflect on failed attempts to the internalizations of businesses from managerial and leadership perspectives (Obj.  4.1).
Recommended Reading: ?There are many books on the subject of international management  any of them will do. Books that are available via www.nebis.ch are listed below:International management: strategic opportunities and cultural challenges (2014). Paul D. Sweeney and Dean B. Mc Farlin. New York: Routledge.International management: managing across borders and cultures (2011). Helen Deresky. Pearson.International management (2005). Jeanne McNett. Serie: The Blackwell encyclopedia of management.International management (2002). David H. Holt| Karen W. Wigginton. Serie: The Harcourt College Punlishers series in management.International management (2009). David Ahlstrom and Garry D.Bruton. Mason  Ohio: South-Western
Title: Module Description

Module Name: Context: The Dynamics of Contemporary International Political Issues
Communication: ?speak knowledgeably on the contents of the required readingsdistinguish inherent bias and critically engage with academic and non-academic specialist sources
Content: Fundamental theoretical positions Understanding the conflicting approaches and of Liberalism vs Mercantilism and Economic Nationalism.Understanding the role of Marx(ism) and Structuralism in shaping attitude in transition states.Critiques Of Traditional Mercantilist  Liberal And Structural Analyses Contemporary Cases and Applications (example themes – a final selection will be made at the start of the module based on real international political)From the American Century to the Asian Century? Changing global power relations.  Conflicts in East and South East Asia – the reemergence of China and its impacts. Europe's responses to global challenges and the role of Europe in the 21st century. Impacts of the US retreat from multilateralism. (Mis)Information Campaigns and International Influence - Russia's destabilisation campaigns. The Politics of Energy. Development Issues and The North-South Debate. Globalisation in Crisis? Students may also suggest particular issues to be analysed
Description: This module is designed to develop the participants' understanding and ability to reflect on complex issues in international politics and international relations by applying a range of analytical tools and concepts from international politics. Over the course of this module  you will strengthen your understanding of the Importance of politics and international relations in the world arena. Students from Switzerland and partners universities will be given the opportunity to work together to examine major international issues and conduct joint analyses integrating insights from their local environment. The module is taught online.
Judgement: ?assess contemporary issues in international politics and international relationsevaluate current international issues which influence international business decision-making.
Knowledge: ?explain key political concepts. identify and explain historical and cultural antecedents of contemporary political conflictsdescribe and differentiate historical economic systems and forces such as Mercantilism  Liberalism and Structuralism and their profound influence on the world today
Title: Module Description

Communication: The students:Present analyses clearly  concisely  and cogently.Offer feedback and critique professionally and constructively.Reflect and receive feedback on their performance in a range of activities and cases.
Content: Studentsstudy key international negotiation and conflict literature  models and theoriesapply theoretical knowledge to their own performance and that of others as shown in case studieswrite a case study based on a real international negotiation from the commercial  political  or diplomatic domains (student selection approved by professor)present their case study and analysis to their peers and professor   Models and theories include:Distributive and Integrative Negotiations & Value Claiming / Value CreationNegotiation AnalysisNegotiation Strategy and TacticsNegotiation BehavioursCross-cultural dimensions of negotiationIntercultural aspects of trust  trust development and trust repair (Culture and Conflict)Power in Negotiations
Description: ?The aim of this module is to deepen the current understanding of international negotiations through the application of a multi-lens approach in which selected theories and models are applied to specific cases to gain richer insight into negotiations and the associated fields of cross-cultural communications and conflict resolution. This module builds upon previous cross-cultural and communications classes and introduces concepts of conflict and conflict management.
Judgement: The students:Can reflect on their communication and negotiations approaches and that of others.Evaluate real negotiation cases through the application of key theories and models  and judge the applicability of negotiation strategies and behaviours to intercultural situations.Understand and can apply appropriate negotiation strategies to international situations.
Knowledge: The students:Know how to prepare  execute  and follow-up on a goal oriented negotiation.Understand the success factors for negotiations in different cultures.
Recommended Reading: Key texts – students should ensure that they have access to these book during the course: Lewicki  Roy J  David M. Saunders  Bruce Barry  and Roy J. Lewicki. Negotiation. Boston  Mass: McGraw-Hill Irwin  2006. Print.  Alternatively Lewicki et al "The Essentials of Negotiation" may also be used.  Mayer  Bernard  The Dynamics of Conflict Resolution: A Practitioner's Guide  San Francisco  Calif.: Jossey-Bass  2000. Additional texts will be provided online.
Title: Module Description

Module Name: Focus: The Ethics of Digital Innovation
Communication: Write a brief report on the case-studyPresent the main points of your analysis of the case-study
Content: The course brings students to address the complete range of questions raised by digital technologies in the context of a company/public institution.Introduction to ethics of innovation (including a crash-course in applied ethics)The ethical challenges of digital technologies: AI ethics  data ethics  design ethicsSocial justice questions in the context of digital technologies: impact on the labor market  impact on social interactions  impact on specific sectors of activities (such as health  public institutions)Responsible research and innovation: the conditions of ethically solid innovation processesGovernance of ethical challenges in companies/public institutions (ethics board  data board)Link to responsible leadership approaches and how digital technologies and their ethical challenges impact leadership
Description: This module addresses the ethical challenges surrounding digital innovation. Digital tools are being used in virtually all domains of activities. They have changed the way companies and public institutions work. They have a large impact on social interactions and on political life. Digital tools and their use across different domains raise important questions regarding society's core values and principles. In short  they raise ethical challenges  which we  as individuals  as company employees or as citizens have to address.  Students will develop ethical competencies relevant to their professional careers  mainly in identifying and addressing ethical challenges and providing potential solutions. After an introduction to ethics of innovation theory  students will be asked to investigate in depth case-studies and develop a comprehensive approach to identify and address ethical challenges in real-world contexts. The topics addressed in the course are complementary to traditional issues of business ethics. They touch upon fields of research such as digital ethics and technology ethics.
Judgement: Evaluate the tensions identified in light of the values of the company/public institution        Justify your position in form of a well formulated argument
Knowledge: Identify ethical challenges in the context of design  development and implementation of digital technologiesDescribe the values at stake and map the ethical challengesExplain the different ways to address ethical challenges
Recommended Reading: Lobschat/Mueller/Eggers/Brandimarte/Diefenbach/Kroschke/Wirtz  "Corporate Digital Responsibility"  Journal of Business Research (2021)
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?low : The student has to explain and defend the innovative idea in front of the class and furthermore interested participants of the university.
Content: On the one hand  concepts are taught through plenary lectures and case studies. Covered topics are :  - Digital Age of Today / Digital Economy in a Digital Society - Digital Disruption / Digital Transformation - Framing Digital Business Development - Digital Business Development - Digital Business Development Portfolio - Digital Maturity Model - Sociotechnical Framework - Agile Business - Digital Eco-System - System-FIT - Sustainability - Business Innovation - Digital Leadership / Management 4.0 - Abili-Methodology  On the other hand  the students have to select an environments  to deepen it in a workshop  to publish the final findings in an FHNW wiki page  and to embed an innovation in one of these environments. Details will be announced in the lecture.
Description: On the one hand  the digital age opens a wide range of new business opportunities - on the other hand  we recognize that the existing management concepts have their origins in the industrial age and are hardly suitable for leading companies into the digital age. Therefore  this module provides new concepts for innovative and responsible managers to face the networked and dynamic digital age.
Judgement: The student has to find an innovative idea that does not exist in Europa up to now and evaluate it with regard to the digitalization of the society and economy  to business development  and to a possible uniqueness.
Knowledge: ?high :On successful completion of this course  a student learned - how digitalization and globalization change the way we do business. - how to recognize future business opportunities in order to enable the development of products  services and business models in the digital economy from the legacy business perspective and from the no-legacy business perspective. - how to perceive relevant trends and how digital means can enable new business models from the legacy business perspective and from the no-legacy business perspective.  - how to build on sustainability in the digital economy. - how to face innovations to create sustainable strategic advantages in the digital economy.
