Module Name: Critical Approach and Business Ethics  Olten
Communication: ?Develop and deliver a logical  persuasive  morally and ethically grounded argument on a chosen subject area in a form of a debate  ensuring morality and ethics (Obj. 3.2)Produce written evaluation of arguments of others' (Obj. 3.1)
Content: Critical Approach  ArgumentsFallaciesRefutationInductive  deductive and causal reasoningEmpirical research: sources and literaturePlagiarism and intellectual property Business EthicsVirtue ethicsEthics of duty (deontology)UtilitarianismTheories of justiceTheories of responsibilityDecision-making models based on theories of economic ethics and business ethics
Description: The module introduces students to principles of ethical  critical  and systematic thinking and offers insights and approaches to responsible decision making in a complex world. Creative and solution-oriented techniques enable students to define structure and analyze problems to develop solutions.  Critical Approach enables students to identify and formulate coherent arguments. Students will also learn to locate and evaluate sources of information. Business Ethics informs students about concepts and frameworks of ethical decision-making. Managers need to understand and comply with ethical standards in order to satisfy expectations of stakeholders.
Follow up module: ?Critical Approach & Business Ethics serves as a foundation for the business administration studies. Skills and techniques acquired in the module will help students in latter semesters.
Judgement: Systematically evaluate research and arguments (Obj. 2.1)Evaluate the quality of literature and the validity empirical evidence and methodologies (Obj. 1.2 & 2.1)Evaluate the actions and their consequences of economic decision makers (Obj. 2.1)
Knowledge: Identify quality information and sourcesIdentify fallacies in an argumentDistinguish between an inductive and deductive argumentation  qualitative  quantitative and empirical researchRecognize the problems of plagiarism and intellectual propertyIdentify the main tenets of philosophical ethics (moral philosophy)  of economic and business ethics  and of moral philosophy and moral economyRecognize other fields of applied ethics  such as information ethics and political ethicsDescribe the ethical relevance and implications of decisions  actions and developmentsIdentify ethically questionable behaviour and draw on the contributions of economic and business ethicsIdentify the main implications of ethical management and of compliance managementDescribe concepts of responsibilityDiscuss the interconnection between economics and ecology
Recommended Reading: ?Marino  G. (2010). Ethics: The Essential Writings. New York: Modern Library. Sharp Paine  L. (2003). Value Shift: Why Companies Must Merge Social and Financial       Imperatives to Achieve Superior Performance. New York: McGraw Hill. Jonas  H. (1984). The Imperative of Responsibility: In Search of an Ethics for the      Technological Age. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
Title: Module Description

Communication: Present and discuss problems and business ideas in classroom activities (focus: high).Be able to present an innovative idea in a pitching session with few minutes. (focus: high)
Content: ?The Innovation in the Digital Age module gives the opportunity to students to conceive and conceptualize a user-centric and innovative idea with a business impact. Techniques from the Design Thinking and the Design Sprint will be taught and additional input will be provided by industry or startup experts. Students are expected to implement the most appropriate techniques to the project work.  The project work is a group work but can also be individual upon request. Students will be supported and supervised through coaching sessions by the lecturers. Students will also train communication skills by presenting the outcome of each phase of the Design Thinking methodology in class.
Description: ?The Innovation of Digital Age is a project-based module that aims to conceive an innovative idea that has a significant impact on the business environment. The idea should lead to a business opportunity  create the basis for a new business model  or to developments with the potential of disrupting current business models. Students are expected to collaborate and co-work in small groups for the creation of a user-centric  specific  innovative  and tangible solution. As such  the solution shall be framed into a prototype and tested with potential customers. This innovation process is supported by Design Thinking  which provides methodological support in the problem/solution fit. Hence  students will learn how to apply each phase of Design Thinking  stressing the problem space and the solution space. The Design Sprint method will be supplemented to support further the Define and Ideate phases. Students are also expected to conduct exhaustive research about the feasibility of the solution  i.e. its economic viability and technological realisability.   The main competencies that will be developed by the students in this course are the following: 1) Innovativeness  which is supported by the application of diverging and converging techniques that focus on the problem and solution spaces.  2) Communication skills  which are supported by both the frequent presentations and the collaboration and co-work in groups.   3) Systematic-methodical approach  which is supported by the application of the Design Thinking methodology and the Design Sprint method.
Judgement: ?Assess the fitting between a problem and a solution (problem-solution fit) (focus: high). Assess the economic viability and technology feasibility of a solution (focus: high).
Knowledge: ?Understand entrepreneurship from an early stage  by focusing on the problem/solution fit (focus: high). Understand the relevance of innovation processes through the Design Thinking and the Design Sprint (focus: high).
Title: Module Description

Communication: Present solutions to BPM cases in a compelling manner (focus: medium / competence: communication skills)
Content: Strategic alignmentProcess governanceProcess improvementProcess innovationProcess and Case ModelingProcesses and DecisionsWorkflowmanagement BPM skills and rolesBPM cultureBPM cases
Description: ?As a holistic approach  business process management (BPM) covers various factors including strategic alignment  governance  lean management  modeling  people  and culture for operating  improving  and innovating business processes. The course introduces fundamental frameworks  models  and methods in BPM and applies them to real-world cases.
Judgement: Assess options for process improvement and innovation (focus: high / competence: problem solving  innovativeness)  Assess BPM-related decisions in organizations (focus: medium / competence: decision-making capacity)
Knowledge: Know the foundations of BPM and understand the relevance of BPM for organizational performance (focus: medium / competence: expertise in BPM  interdisciplinary knowledge)  Know key frameworks  models  and methods of BPM and understand when to apply them (focus: high / competence: expertise in BPM  interdisciplinary knowledge)

Business Process Management Cases: Digital Innovation and Business Transformation in Practice. Berlin: Springer.Dumas  M.  La Rosa  M.  Mendling  J.  & Reijners  H. A. (2018). Fundamentals of Business Process Management. Berlin: Springer.Silver  B. (2011). BPMN Method and Style  Second Edition (Second Edi.). Aptos  CA: Cody-Cassidy Press.OMG: CMMN Case Management Model and NotationVon Halle  B.  & Goldberg  L. (2010). The Decision Model: A Business Logic Framework Linking Business and Technology. CRC Press Auerbach Publications.Mary Beth Chrissis et al.: CMMI for Development®: Guidelines for Process Integration and Product Improvement  3rd Edition  Addison-Wesley  2011.Stephan Lunau (Ed.) et al.: Six Sigma + Lean Toolset: Mindset for Successful Implementation of Improvement Projects  2nd Edition  Springer  2013.
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Medium: ability to prepare and present short presentations and write a report about topics in the field of IT governance  compliance and/or risk management  inclusive an assessment of consequences and/or value proposition trade-off (communication skills).
Content: The course starts by showing and discussing which current regulatory requirements are relevant to (large) companies and how they can be systematically translated into an entrepreneurial context. We discuss the approaches of (regulatory) audits and quality assurance assessments. In addition  we analyse well-established "tools" (e.g. COBIT 2019  ISO 38500  31000  20000 (ITIL)) and their benefits in different settings. We work with a dedicated software solution to learn and analyze the application and combination of different reference models. Practically  we audit the effectiveness of "internal controls" in selected companies. During the classroom sessions  there is the possibility to discuss with invited practitioners and to benefit from their experiences.
Description: To run a business efficiently requires a coordinated strategic and operational approach. Various standards  frameworks and so-called "best practices" offer recommendations for action on a variety of topics and  not least  on dealing with regulatory requirements that have to be mapped in an entrepreneurial context. The course focuses on strategic and operational methods and is organized in four interrelated themes - with a particular focus on the needs of digitization and information technology: (1) Compliance in the context of specific industries and different company sizes. (2) Risk identification  assessment and related actions. (3) Governance as (top) management activity and monitoring duties . (4) Audit as a control  coaching and monitoring duty. An important and dedicated topic of the course is data privacy compliance| we discuss the new European Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)  its impact on business processes and the required data management. The practical part of this course will be the application of a selected software solution for the operationalization and auditing of Internal Control Systems (ICS). Using this software  participants can select and compile reference models and standards and schedule and execute related audits.
Judgement: ?Medium: ability to propose necessary activities or controls based on a systematic and well-documented gap analysis/audit (results-oriented action).
Knowledge: ?High: knowledge about the challenges and opportunities facing decision makers in (large) enterprises with IT-related regulations and the transformation in decisions  at least in processes and activities (Problem-solving competence). Understanding (analytical skills) about the rapidly increasing requirements in terms of compliance  governance and risk management (based on practical cases and experience). Good understanding about the relationship between (IT) governance  risk and compliance as well as the role of (IT) audit . Privacy requirements as a special expertise focused on the EU GDPR.
Recommended Reading: Material provided on Moodle
Title: Module Description

Communication: Die Studierenden:können Konzepte und Lösungen zielgruppengerecht und unter Verwendung der einschlägigen Terminologie in schriftlicher und mündlicher Form präsentieren
Content: Inhalte Modul 1 HR-Strategie  Struktur & OrganisationZusammenhang von Personalpolitik  HR-Strategie und UnternehmensstrategieEntwicklung eines HR-Portfolios und einer HR-RoadmapFormen und Funktionen formaler OrganisationenProzessorganisation und agile TransformationUnterschiede von HR-OrganisationsformenEinsatz von Mitarbeitenden in international tätigen UnternehmenAktuelle Ansätze des Diversity ManagementsBedeutung und Handlungsfelder des Betrieblichen GesundheitsmanagementCorporate Social Responsibility und Rolle des HRM Inhalte Modul 2 Change & LeadershipKlassische Ansätze im Change ManagementRelevante Konzepte zur VeränderungAnsätze zum Umgang mit VeränderungZiele und Inhalte von BeratungsprozessenMethoden und Instrumente der lösungsorientierten BeratungEckpunkte des Digital HR: Strategie  Prozesse  KulturRolle des HR und digitale HR-TransformationFührungsverständnis und Alltagstheorien der FührungKlassische und neue Führungstheorien und ihre Anwendungsmöglichkeiten
Description: Die heutige Arbeitswelt ist von immer schnellerem Wandel geprägt. Ein modernes Human Resource Management (HRM) stellt sich dieser Herausforderung  entwickelt Strategien und Konzepte für Menschen und Organisationen und setzt diese im Unternehmen um. Die Digitalisierung ermöglicht neue Arbeits- und Organisationsformen  die ein innovatives HRM mitgestaltet. Gefragt sind Fachpersonen  die bewährte und neue Instrumente des HRM und der Organisationsentwicklung überprüfen  anpassen und entwickeln können.  Studierende lernen  mit welchen Veränderungen Organisationen und ihre Mitarbeitenden konfrontiert sind  wie ein strategisch ausgerichtetes HRM im Unternehmen organisiert ist  wie bewährte Konzepte und Instrumente der Führung  Personalentwicklung  Lohngestaltung und der Talent Akquisition angewendet und weiterentwickelt und die Arbeitsbedingungen der Mitarbeitenden verbessert werden und schliesslich wie sie dazu beitragen können  diesen Wandel zu gestalten.
Judgement: Die Studierenden:können einordnen  welche Implikationen die verschiedenen Konzepte für Unternehmen  Führungskräfte und Mitarbeitende haben können die Praxisrelevanz verschiedener Ansätze kritisch reflektieren und einordnen
Knowledge: Die Studierenden:?kennen und verstehen Theorien  Modelle und Konzepte  die für ein modernes HRM relevant sindkönnen beschreiben wie Unternehmen und das HR organisiert werdekönnen die Entwicklung und die Bedeutung einer HR-Strategie beschreibenkennen die Herausforderungen des HRM in internationalen Organisationenverstehen die Relevanz von Gesundheitsmanagement  Diversity Management und Corporate Social Responsibility für Organisationenverstehen verschiedene Ansätze des Change Managementskennen Methoden und Instrumente der lösungsorientierten Beratungverstehen die Rolle des HR in der digitalen HR-Transformationkennen Führungstheorien und ihre Anwendungsmöglichkeiten

Human Resource Management (11.Ed). Pearson.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: Students are able present work articulately and convincingly?
Content: This elective module aims at the very much advanced student seeking to be challenged by real-world cases from different areas  be it mergers & acquisitions  digitalization  turning companies around  managing change  coping with a crisis or another topic of general interest. During the class  the students will get an introduction on challenges organizations are facing while adapting to an increasingly complex and uncertain world (incl. technological  economic  political  and cultural changes). Of special interest is how organizational development and disruptive information technologies can be linked. A typical class structure will consist of an introduction from the guest manager's side followed by student group works. The lectures would provide their professional background and talk about one to three occurrences of importance (change process  merger or acquisition  crisis  turn-around  major project  digital transformations etc.) that they have witnessed or led up-front (“This is what I found and had to cope with.”). They will offer these ‘stories’ as case studies that the students will later have to deal with in groups. The students will diagnose the situation and develop a shared understanding of how to plan and implement the change. The students will compete against each other in terms of innovative solutions including a sound implementation plan. Dealing with cases will also involve role-play. Finally  the students’ solutions will be complimented by the real-case scenario (“This is how I or others actually did in order to cope with the challenge. And this is what happened.”) presented by the guest manager in class.?   The module is based on inputs (lecture  case studies) provided by 9 top managers and leaders from international companies and assignments on the content provided during the class. Dealing with challenging cases  students will learn interactively by developing solutions and having them challenged by the lecturing manager. Various topics covering a number of areas related to international management and organization development (the topics depend on the guest managers’ areas of expertise and experience). The class structure and teaching methods employed will be interactive in nature  and participants will be required to present their solutions both orally (as presentations) and in a written format to complement the learning outcomes.?
Description: This elective module is based on inputs (lectures  case studies) provided by top managers and leaders from international companies and assignments on the content provided during the class. The lecture present cases from real-world and the students are asked to challenge the leaders’ work  develop solutions/recommendation and engage with a reflective process to encourage professional and personal development.
Judgement: Students are ableto critically reflect upon their mental models and their impact on the identified leadership challenges (Systems thinking / Ganzheitliches Denken)
Knowledge: Students are ableto identify and describe key challenges of top-managers and leaders (Descion-making ability / Entscheidungsfähigkeit)
Recommended Reading: Senge  P. M. (1994). The Fifth Discipline Fieldbook: Strategies and Tools for Building a Learning Organization  New York: Currency  Doubleday.Wheatley  M. J. (2005). Finding Our Way: Leadership for an Uncertain Time  San Francisco: Berrett-Koehler Publisher ?
Title: Module Description

Content: This module will include the following topics  * Data Preprocessing including Data Cleaning  Data Transformation and Data Discretization * Overfitting/Underfitting  Resampling and Model Selection * Supervised Learning including different forms of regression  classification and decision tree learner * Unsupervised Learning including agglomerative and divisive clustering * Artificial Neural Networks   ** Feed forward networks with different optimisers and activation functions   ** Other types of ANN including Convolution Networks  Recurrent Networks  Long Short-Term Memories (LSTM)  and Kohonen Maps   ** Reinforcement Learning   ** Transfer Learning
Description: More and more companies are going to understand that insights out of their data are crucial for their business success. Some people say  data is the new oil in a digitalized economy. But how do we get insights from data? How do we discover the knowledge hidden in data? For this purpose  many different techniques and algorithms were developed. This module explores the prominent representatives from the artificial intelligence and machine learning area – including prominently the very popular neural networks. We will understand how the algorithms work and how to adjust them – in order to be able to apply them in practice. We apply them on realistic data sets and will get knowledge about their strengths and weaknesses. This module will include exercises in the programming language “R”. It will be taught with a mixture of online and onsite lectures while onsite lectures are prefered.
Judgement: ?Students can apply  evaluate and interpret the discussed machine learning algorithms (descision support)  in particular supervised and unsupervised learning. They can compare the results of different models for selected machine learning tasks such as classification or clustering.
Knowledge: Students learn how to extract knowledge out of data. They will understand the basic principles of selected machine learning algorithms applied by data scientists. Neural Networks will also be investigated.
Title: Module Description

Description: Eine professionelle interne und externe Kommunikation trägt massgeblich zum Gesamterfolg von Unternehmen  Non-Profit-Organisationen und der öffentlichen Verwaltung bei. Betriebsökonomen und -ökonominnen  die sich für eine Tätigkeit in der internen Kommunikation  der Unternehmens- oder Marketingkommunikation interessieren  benötigen deshalb solide Grundkenntnisse der Organisationskommunikation und müssen die neusten digitalen Kommunikationsformen kennen.   Die Studienrichtung Unternehmenskommunikation zeigt die Wichtigkeit einer disziplinenübergreifenden Kommunikation in Organisationen sowie die Zusammenhänge und die Erfolgsfaktoren der Kommunikation in Organisationen auf. Sie vermittelt den Studierenden das notwendige Wissen für eine systematisch betriebene integrierte Kommunikation mit den wichtigsten Zielgruppen einer Organisation auf Basis von relevanten Kommunikationsinhalten  attraktiven Kommunikationsplattformen und wirkungsvollen Kommunikationsinstrumenten.
Judgement: ?Die Studierendenerkennen die Trends in der digitalen Kommunikation und die Auswirkungen auf die interne Kommunikation sowie die Marketing- und Unternehmenskommunikationkönnen die Kommunikation in Organisationen auf verschiedenen Ebenen analysierenerkennen durch analysierte Praxisbeispiele die Erfolgs- und Misserfolgsfaktoren in der Kommunikation von Organisationenkönnen die Qualität von Content in der Kommunikation von Organisationen beurteilensind fähig  Praxisbeispiele aus der visuellen Kommunikation (etwa typografische Layouts  Infografiken  Videos  Schriftarten  Firmenlogos  Bildwelten) auf formale und inhaltliche Kriterien  kritisch zu beurteilenkönnen den Einsatz eines Printmediums zur Erreichung der Kommunikationsziele und die Inhaltsstruktur von Printprodukten beurteilenkönnen die Wirkungen eines Events abschätzen und optimieren
Knowledge: ?Die Studierenden kennen die Bedeutung der internen und externen Kommunikation in Profitunternehmen  Nonprofit-Organisationen und der öffentlichen Verwaltungdie Aufgaben  Rolle  Funktion  Einbettung und Trends der Kommunikation in Organisationendas FHNW-Modell des integrierten Kommunikationsmanagementsdas Management von erfolgsrelevanten Themen (Issues) in Organisationendie Charakteristiken der gängigen Inhaltsformate (Content) in der Kommunikation die Storytelling-Methode zur Erhöhung von Kommunikationswirkungendie Bedeutung und Wirkung der visuellen Inhaltsvermittlung mit Bild  Typografie  Grafik  Infografik und Video (Corporate Design) den Entwicklungsprozess von Video- und Grafikdesign-Projektendie Bedeutung  Typen  Konzeption und Produktion von Printmedien in der Unternehmenspublizistikdie Mechanismen  und Erfolgsfaktoren der Live-Kommunikation in der internen und externen Kommunikation von Organisationen
Recommended Reading: Weitere Unterlagen zu den einzelnen Themen werden von den Dozierenden bekanntgegeben/erstellt und im Unterricht abgegeben (in der Regel eigene Skripte/Folien).

Communication: ?Develop and deliver a logical  persuasive  morally and ethically grounded argument on a chosen subject area in a form of a debate  ensuring morality and ethics (Obj. 3.2)Produce written evaluation of arguments of others' (Obj. 3.1)
Content: ? Critical Approach  ArgumentsFallaciesRefutationInductive  deductive and causal reasoningEmpirical research: sources and literaturePlagiarism and intellectual property Business EthicsVirtue ethicsEthics of duty (deontology)UtilitarianismTheories of justiceTheories of responsibilityDecision-making models based on theories of economic ethics and business ethics
Description: ? The module introduces students to principles of ethical  critical  and systematic thinking and offers insights and approaches to responsible decision making in a complex world. Creative and solution-oriented techniques enable students to define structure and analyze problems to develop solutions. Critical Approach enables students to identify and formulate coherent arguments. Students will also learn to evaluate sources of information. Business Ethics informs students about concepts and frameworks of ethical decision-making. Managers need to understand and comply with ethical standards in order to satisfy expectations of stakeholders.
Follow up module: ?Critical Approach & Business Ethics serves as a foundation for Business Administration (IM) studies as a whole. Skills and techniques acquired in the module will help students in latter semesters.
Judgement: ?Systematically evaluate research and arguments (Obj. 2.1)Evaluate the quality of literature and the validity of empirical evidence and methodologies (Obj. 1.2 & 2.1)Evaluate the actions and their consequences of economic decision makers (Obj. 2.1)
Knowledge: ?Identify quality information and sourcesIdentify fallacies in an argumentDistinguish between an inductive and deductive argumentation  qualitative  quantitative and empirical researchRecognize the problems of plagiarism and intellectual propertyIdentify the main tenets of philosophical ethics (moral philosophy)  of economic and business ethics  and of moral philosophy and moral economyRecognize other fields of applied ethics  such as information ethics and political ethicsDescribe the ethical relevance and implications of decisions  actions and developmentsIdentify ethically questionable behaviour and draw on the contributions of economic and business ethicsIdentify the main implications of ethical management and of compliance managementDescribe concepts of responsibilityDiscuss the interconnection between economics and ecology
Recommended Reading: ? Marino  G. (2010). Ethics: The Essential Writings. New York: Modern Library. Sharp Paine  L. (2003). Value Shift: Why Companies Must Merge Social and Financial         Imperatives to Achieve Superior Performance. New York: McGraw Hill. Jonas  H. (1984). The Imperative of Responsibility: In Search of an Ethics for the       Technological Age. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Developing an academic writing style suited to empirical analysis.Developing a writing style suited to a comparative analysis.
Content: ?Thematic Overview of Teaching Sessions Day 1 Teaching Session 1 (lesson 1-3): The Varieties of National Economic Systems (NES) Day 1 Teaching Session 2 (lesson 4-7): National Economic Systems and Firm Strategy Day 2 Teaching Session 3 (lesson 8-10): Workshop on Comparative Empirical Analysis of NES - Data  Day 2 Teaching Session 4 (lesson 11-12): European and North American National Economic Systems Day 2 Teaching Session 4 (lesson 13-14): Asian National Economic Systems Day 3 Teaching Session 5 (lesson 15-17): Workshop on Comparative Empirical Analysis of NES - Analysis  Day 3 Teaching Session 6 (lesson 18-19): Latin American National Economic Systems  Day 3 Teaching Session 6 (lesson 20-21): NES of understudied countries  including African countries
Description: ?The majority of national economic systems in the world today are arguably based on the principles of the market economy. There is however a significant variety of ways in which the market economy is realized by different countries  for example the UK  Germany and France have very different economic systems. Each of these national economic systems takes a different approach to the nature and role of institutions such as industrial relations (firms and their employees)  employee relations (working conditions)  corporate governance  the teaching and education system and inter-firm relations. As a result different national economies can represent very different environments within which to do business  with important implications for issues such as business innovation  how firms are managed  the legitimacy of business activities and decisions etc. This module will support you in developing an understanidng of these nuances and then in their applciation to analyse national economic insitutions to allow better strategic decision-making.
Follow up module: ?All modules that require an understanding of business activities within their broader environment nationally or internationally.
Judgement: ?Evaluating the implications of the similarities and differences between national economic systems for firm strategy.Recommend strategic action based on the analysis of data.
Knowledge: explain  the diversity of national economic systems. the discuss implications of the national economic systems for businesses.
Recommended Reading: ?A number or further recommended readings will be made available via Moodle.
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?create meaningful reports using descriptive statistics and visualizations for a range of stakeholders
Content: Introduction to the use of fact-based decision makingBasics of business performance managementExplorative data analysis: application and use of visualization and corresponding toolsIntroduction to data mining and definition of simple data mining tasksBig Data: challenges and opportunitiesIntroduction to text mining and real-time data analyses
Description: ?Managers cannot base their decisions just on intuition| decisions must be informed by evidence.  As the result of digitalization  the amount of available information from business processes keeps on increasing  which in turn creates both challenges and opportunities for decision-making. Traditional fact-based decision-making uses data to “steer” a company. Increasingly  data are used to automate operational decisions  to anticipate and avoid risks and to seize opportunities. There is a trend to collect and exploit ever more fine-grained information on customer behavior or use of products that could traditionally only be observed in the real world and use such information to innovate  by improving products/services  or even business models.
Judgement: set the KPIs and determine the impact of KPIs for the measurement of goal achievementmake judgement on when real-time analytics are neededdetermine when text mining to semi- or unstructured data should be useddetermine if predictive analytics can be used to automate / support operational decisions.select the right text mining instruments for given textual data
Knowledge: explain the need for fact-based decision making and the basic possibilities for supporting itexplain the limitations of predictive analyticsdescribe the role of big data in an innovation cycle and be able to derive analytical "bottom-up scenarios"explain the limitations of text mining instrumentsrecognize situations in which predictive analytics can be used to automate / support operational decisions (e.g. fraud detection  marketing etc.)recognize the potentials of applying text mining to semi- or unstructured data in terms of e.g. understanding customer needs
Recommended Reading: Kimball  R.  & Ross  M. (2013). The Data Warehouse Toolkit. 3rd Ed. Wiley Computer Publishing.R. Kimball  R.  Ross  M.  Thornthwaite  W.  Mundy  J.  & Becker  B. (2008). The Data Warehouse Lifecycle Toolkit. Wiley Computer Publishing.Marr  B. (2012). Key Performance Indicators – the 75 meaures every manager needs to know. FT Publishing.Tan  P.  Steinbach  M.  & Kumar  V. (2005). Introduction to Data Mining. Addison Wesley.Feldman  R.  & Sanger  J. (2007). The Text Mining Handbook  Cambridge University Press.
