Communication: The students are able to present concepts and solutions in a written and oral way (Obj. 3.2)
Content: Definitions  terminology  typologies of entrepreneurship/intrapreneurship and innovation| Characteristics of entrepreneurshipApproaches and strategies in the field of entrepreneurship / intrapreneurship (e.g. Lean Startup  Blue Ocean Strategy or the like).Innovation strategy| Innovation process|  Organization / innovation structures| Methods and tools for the identification  development and implementation of innovative concepts and solutions| Innovation-relevant aspects of the corporate culture| Innovation-promoting and inhibiting factors in the business environment (e.g. innovation system and ecosystem)| Protection of intellectual property| Analyzing business models and developing elements of a business plan| Financing start-ups|  Responsible / sustainable innovation & social entrepreneurshipBusiness ideas and models
Description: Internationalization  automation  digitization and an increasing awareness of sustainability are leading to shorter product cycles  requiring new process designs and business models. In addition  the competition between companies is becoming more and more dynamic and competitive advantages are changing rapidly. The module Entrepreneurship & Innovation provides the tools to understand and successfully implement innovation and entrepreneurial initiative. It appeals to business administration students who want to qualify and position themselves as future leaders in Entrepreneurship & Innovation. It provides an overview of current concepts and models based on relevant literature and recent case studies.  In practical exercises ideas are generated  business models are analyzed and current case studies are worked on.
Judgement: Students can judge and justify whether and why a particular method is suitable for a task (Obj. 2.1)
Knowledge: ?  Students canname  describe and classify the different definitions and typologies of entrepreneurship and innovation describe the importance of innovation for organizations and economies name  describe and classify methods for innovation and entrepreneurship name and describe the different phases of the innovation process  cite promotional and inhibiting factors of the innovation success.
Recommended Reading: ?Ahmed  P.  & Shepherd  C. (2010). Innovation Management. Pearson Higher Education.Banks  K.  Ed. (2016)  Social Entrepreneuship and Innovation: International Case Studies and Practice  London: KoganPage.Smith  D. (2015). Exploring Innovation. 3rd edition  London: McGraw-Hill Education.Tidd  J.  Bessant  J. (2013). Managing Innovation: Integrating Technological  Market and Organizational Change  5th edition  Wiley.Tidd  J.  Bessant  J. (2015).Innovation and Entrepreneurship.3rd edition  Wiley.
Title: Module Description

Module Name: Focus: Social Entrepreneurship for Economic Development
Communication: ?Enhance communication skills through working cross-culturally in a village and within multicultural team. Learn to communicate to social entrepreneurs in their own way.
Content: Our aim is to ensure a flow of knowledge about entrepreneurial methods and skills into the rural areas. On the other hand  we trust that through this programme participants will learn to work effectively and adjust quickly to a new socio-cultural context by working with local people to create innovative solutions  based on the resources and talents available and the context of the place. What participants will learn:  - Why we need social entrepreneurship.  - How to indetify a social problem to tackle.  - What need to plan for sustainability.  - How to bring idea to scale and to build a business model to launch a social enterprise.
Description: Social Enterprise for Economic Development (SEED) is a cross-cultural program utilizing social entrepreneurship as means towards economic progress. The Program seeks to provide off-campus cross-cultural experiences that will enable participants to advance in the application of research-based strategies  theories and principles. Further  it also seeks to promote transformative education through inter-cultural exposures. ?The  module aims to train students in social entrepreneurship and offers  cross-cultural management experience in a foreign environment.  Participants will be provided with a platform to work with management students abroad.   Participants will learn to operate in new socio-cultural contexts as  entrepreneurs  strategists and change agents (leaders) in order to bring  about sustainable economic development through their enterprising  efforts for the community.
Judgement: Examine how free-enterprise economies work and how entrepreneurs fit into them.Determine how to work cross-culturally and enhance the entrepreneurial mindset  a mindset to tackle problems across different sectors (public  private  non-profit)
Knowledge: Identify  a problem they care about  understand the considerations needed for  impact and financial sustainability  and learn about how various  entrepreneurs have thought about scale.Recognize and evaluate business opportunities based on the analysis of local conditions with their own individual skills. Identify how profit works as a signal to the entrepreneurExplain the concept of social entrepreneurship and be inspired to find new ways to tackle the world's greatest challenges.
Recommended Reading: Bjerke  B.  and Karlsson  M. (2013)  "Social Entrepreneurship: to act as if and make a difference"  Cheltenham: Edward Elgar.Cole  A. (1959)  "Business Enterprise in its Society Setting"  Cambridge  MA: Harvard University Press.Hisrich  R. D.  Peter  M. P.  and Shepherd  D. A. (2013)  "Entrepreneurship"  McGraw Hill. Holland  B (1997)  "Analyzing institutional commitment to service: a model of key organizational factors"  Michigan Journal of Community Service Learning 4.Kent  C. A.  Anderson  L. P. (2004)  "Social Capital  Social Entrepreneurship  and Entrepreneurship Education"  International Journal of Entrepreneurship Education 2  No.1. Shapero  A. (1975)  "Entrepreneurship and Economic Development"  Wisconsin: Project ISEED  Ltd  The Center for Venture Management  Summer.
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Die Studierenden ...            sind in der Lage  ein Projekt zum Erfolg zu führen und dabei die Auftraggeberschaft jederzeit und transparent auf dem Laufenden zu halten  sowie den generierten Mehrwert personenspezifisch zu vermitteln.sind in der Lage  eigene Arbeitsergebnisse für eine bestimmte Zielgruppe in mündlicher Form verständlich und überzeugend darzustellen.sind in der Lage  eigene Arbeitsergebnisse für eine bestimmte Zielgruppe in schriftlicher Form verständlich und überzeugend darzustellen.
Content: Projektmanagement - GrundlagenVom Projektauftrag zum ProjektzielProjektrisiken / QualitätssicherungProjektorganisationPlanung  Steuerung und ÜberwachungMethoden / Tools in der täglichen ProjektarbeitSoziale Kompetenz in Projekten Konfliktmanagement Exkurs : Verfügbare Modelle
Description: ?Projektmanagement in der Wirtschaftsinformatik bedeutet  einem Unternehmen bzw. einer Organisation in einem definierten Zeitrahmen mit einem definierten Budget einen definierten Mehrwert zu generieren.
Judgement: ?Die Studierenden ...            sind in der Lage  unternehmerische Probleme  die ein Projekt begründen könnten  unternehmerisch zu bewerten und auf deren operationale Lösbarkeit hin einzuschätzen.sind in der Lage  die Funktionalitäten und Einsatzmöglichkeiten bestehender Standardanwendungen zu analysieren und deren potenziellen Nutzen für verschiedene Einsatzfelder im Unternehmen zu beurteilen.sind in der Lage  Informationen über aktuelle IT-Trends selbständig aufzufinden  auszuwerten und deren Bedeutung für die Anwendung in Organisationen kritisch einzuschätzen.
Knowledge: ?Die Studierenden ...verstehen die Probleme und Wechselbeziehungen im Managen komplexer Projekte der Wirtschaftsinformatik und Wirtschaft. Die Modellierung und Optimierung von Geschäftsprozessen ist implizit Gegenstand des Moduls und wird einführend angesprochen.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: Die Studierenden legen ihre ökonomische Argumentation in schriftlichen und mündlichen Beiträgen überzeugend dar.  verfassen adressatengerechte kurze Stellungnahmen und kleine Berichte.  (Obj. 3.1)
Content: Wirtschaftspolitik (Ziele  Indikatoren  Instrumente  Träger  Zielbeziehungen  Werthaltungen)   Volkswirtschaftliche Gesamtrechnung (Wertschöpfung  Wohlstand und Wohlfahrt)  Zahlungsbilanz und Auslandvermögen  Konjunkturtheorie und -politik (Konjunkturindikatoren und -prognosen  Modell des gesamtwirtschaftlichen Gütermarktes  Konzeptionen der Stabilisierungspolitik  Einkommen-Ausgaben-Modell) Konsumtheorien  Ersparnis und Investitionen Fiskalpolitik (Fiskalimpuls  Schuldenbremse) Geldtheorie und -politik (Geldmengen  Geldschöpfungsprozess  Bankensystem  Reformideen für das Geldsystem  Geldpolitisches Konzept der Schweizerischen Nationalbank  Instrumente der Geldpolitik  monetärer Transmissionsmechanismus  Geld- und Währungspolitik der SNB)  Offene Volkswirtschaften  Aussenhandelstheorie im Überblick  Aussenhandelspolitik  Protektionismus  Ziele und Aufgaben der Welthandelsorganisation Währungsordnungen (nominaler und realer Wechselkurs  Wechselkurssysteme)  Arbeitslosigkeit (Indikatoren  Erwerbsbeteiligung  Schweizer Arbeitsmarkt)  Geldwertstörungen (Indikatoren  Ursachen und Folgen von Inflation und Deflation  nominale und reale Grössen  Inflation und Arbeitslosigkeit)  Wachstumstheorie und -politik  Grenzen des Wachstums  Nachhaltige Entwicklung  Umwelt- und Energiepolitik  Strukturwandel und Strukturpolitik  Sozial- und Finanzpolitik  Staatsschulden  Ausgewählte Aspekte (aktuelle Fragestellungen  Vertiefungen  Anwendungen)
Description: Die Studierenden analysieren und beurteilen das ökonomische Umfeld wirtschaftlicher Entscheidungsträger mit Hilfe von Methoden und Modellen der Makroökonomie. Die Studierenden erklären die kurzfristigen und langfristigen gesamtwirtschaftlichen Zusammenhänge und sind dadurch in der Lage  einen Beitrag zur Lösung konkreter betriebswirtschaftlicher Problemstellungen zu leisten.   ?
Judgement: Die Studierenden  beurteilen die Wirkung wirtschaftspolitischer Massnahmen aus gesamtwirtschaftlicher Sicht. erläutern gesamtwirtschaftliche Entwicklungen und gewichten die Folgen von relevanten Zukunfts- szenarien bezüglich konkreter Problemstellungen von Unternehmen  Haushalten und Staat. (Obj. 1.1)  nehmen zu konkreten und aktuellen ökonomischen Fragestellungen aus unterschiedlichen Perspektiven begründet Stellung. Dabei zeigen sie den allfälligen Einfluss von individuellen Werthaltungen auf die Bevorzugung bestimmter Ziele sowie auf die Wahl konkreter Massnahmen auf.
Knowledge: Die Studierenden  erklären gesamtwirtschaftliche Statistiken und beschreiben deren Grenzen. erklären Ursachen und Folgen von Störungen am gesamtwirtschaftlichen Gütermarkt und zeigen die Wirkungsweise stabilisierungspolitischer Massnahmen mit Hilfe von Modellen auf. erläutern die Grundzüge der schweizerischen Fiskalpolitik (Finanzpolitik). Sie erklären das geldpolitische Konzept sowie die geldpolitischen Lagebeurteilungen der Schweizerischen Nationalbank und erläutern ihre Geld- und Währungspolitik.  erklären die Bestimmungsfaktoren und die Entwicklung von nominalen und realen Wechsel- kursen in unterschiedlichen Währungsordnungen und Wechselkursystemen. Sie zeigen kurz- sowie langfristige Zusammenhänge zwischen Wechselkursen und Zahlungsbilanz  Arbeitslosigkeit sowie Inflation auf.  erklären Gründe für den globalen Aussenhandel und zeigen die Folgen von Freihandel und Protektionismus auf.  nennen die wichtigsten Bestimmungsfaktoren des Wirtschaftswachstums und fassen die Ursachen des Strukturwandels zusammen.  beschreiben die Ziele der Wirtschaftspolitik und untersuchen deren gegenseitige Beziehungen.
Recommended Reading: keine?
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: Die Studierendenverwenden das korrekte Fachvokabular für ihre mündlichen und schriftlichen Ausführungen.legen ihre ökonomische Argumentation in schriftlichen und mündlichen Beiträgen überzeugend dar.verfassen adressatengerechte kurze Stellungnahmen und kleine Berichte.  (Obj. 3.1)
Content: Grundlagen der Volkswirtschaftslehre (Mikro- und Makroökonomie  Knappheit  Opportunitätskosten  Anreize  Modelle  positive und normative Ökonomik) Wettbewerbsmodell (vollständige/vollkommene Konkurrenz)Nachfragetheorie (Nutzen  Konsumentscheidung  Elastizitäten)Angebotstheorie (Kostentheorie  Produktionsentscheidung  Elastizitäten)Angebot und Nachfrage  Märkte und Preise  staatliche Eingriffe in das Marktgeschehen (Preis- und Mengeneingriffe  Wohlfahrtsanalyse)Faktormärkte (Arbeitsmärkte  Boden- bzw. Immobilienmärkte  Kapitalmärkte)Marktversagen  Rolle des StaatesUnvollkommener Wettbewerb (Monopol  Oligopol  monopolistische Konkurrenz)  Spieltheorie (Methode  Gefangenendilemma)  Wettbewerbsrecht und -politik (Wettbewerbsgesetz  Kartellgesetz  Preisüberwacher)Marktversagen bei Externalitäten (Umweltpolitik  Patentrecht  Netzwerkexternalitäten)Marktversagen bei öffentlichen Gütern (Private Güter  Clubgüter  Allmendegüter  Kollektivgüter)Marktversagen bei asymmetrischer Information (Risiko  Information) Einkommens- und Vermögensverteilung  Steuern (Gerechtigkeit und Effizienz) und Staatsausgaben  kollektive EntscheidungsfindungAusgewählte Aspekte (aktuelle Fragestellungen  Vertiefungen  Anwendungen)
Description: ?Die Studierenden analysieren und beurteilen das ökonomische Umfeld wirtschaftlicher Entscheidungsträger mit Hilfe von Methoden und Modellen der Mikroökonomie. Die Studierenden erklären die Wechselbeziehungen von Unternehmen  Haushalten und Staat und sind dadurch in der Lage  einen Beitrag zur Lösung konkreter betriebswirtschaftlicher Problemstellungen zu leisten.
Judgement: ?Die Studierendenanalysieren die Realität mit Hilfe von Konzepten und Modellen der Ökonomie und überprüfen ihre Anwendbarkeit und Schlussfolgerungen für konkret vorliegende Problemstellungen kritisch. (Obj. 1.1) beurteilen staatliche Regulierung aus wohlfahrtsökonomischer Sicht und zeigen die Interessen von Unternehmen und anderen Wirtschaftssubjekten auf.nehmen zu konkreten und aktuellen ökonomischen Fragestellungen aus unterschiedlichen Perspektiven begründet Stellung. (Obj. 1.1)
Knowledge: Die Studierendenbeschreiben  wie Märkte funktionieren  und vergleichen Märkte mit unterschiedlichen Konkurrenzsituationen sowie Märkte verschiedenartiger Güter.nennen wichtige Merkmale der Märkte für Produktionsfaktoren und schätzen für die Beteiligten die Folgen von Änderungen auf diesen Faktormärkten ein.erläutern die Wirkung von wirtschaftspolitischen Rahmenbedingungen und Massnahmen bezüglich Angebot und Nachfrage sowohl auf Güter- als auch auf Faktormärkten auf die beteiligten Wirtschaftssubjekte.
Recommended Reading: ?keine
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: ?Die Studierenden ...       ... kennen die wichtigen Begriffe der Betriebswirtschaftslehre  des Integralen Managements und können diese korrekt anwenden.... können die Inhalte des Moduls zielgruppengerecht präsentieren.
Content: Einführung in die Betriebswirtschaftslehre Unternehmen als Element der WirtschaftTypologie der UnternehmungGewinnorientierte Unternehmungen und Non-Profit-OrganisationenWertschöpfungskettenStandort (Grad der geographischen Ausbreitung / Standortfaktoren)Unternehmungsziele und gegenseitige Zielbeziehungen      Integrales Management Modellbegriff und ModellbildungAktionsparameter des Managements und ausgewählte Managementmodelle Integrales ManagementmodellSt. Galler ManagementmodellChange Management       Überblick über grundlegende FunktionsbereichenUnternehmungsführung: Funktionen  Managementstufen. Das Managementsystem einer Unternehmung im GesamtzusammenhangOrganisationPersonalmanagementLeadership       Aktuelle Themen Industrie 4.0
Description: Die moderne Marktwirtschaft stellt hohe Anforderung an Unternehmungen und Organisationen was ihr verantwortungs­volles Handeln  ihre Rollen und ihre Vernetzung bei den in- und externen Wertschöpfungsprozessen anbelangt. Das Modul Integrales Management vermittelt Grundlagen  um aus den Erwartungen der Wirtschaft echte Potenziale für Firmen und Mitarbeitende zu schöpfen. Die Studierenden verstehen die Rolle von Unternehmungen und Organisationen – private  gemischtwirtschaftliche oder öffentliche – als offene soziale Systeme  die für ihr Umfeld und ihre Stakeholder Werte schaffen.
Judgement: ?Die Studierenden ...       ... sind in der Lage  praktische Problemstellungen zu analysieren und daraus Schlussfolgerungen zu ziehen.
Knowledge: Die Studierenden …...verstehen die verschiedenen Rollen der Unternehmung innerhalb der gesamten Wirtschaft.… verstehen ausgewählte betriebswirtschaftliche Modelle  deren Inhalte und Strukturen .
Recommended Reading: Zum Beispiel und Weiteres:Textauszug zu «Das neue St. Galler Management Modell» S. 65 – 141Thommen  J.-P.: Betriebswirtschaft und Management| aktuelle Auflage| Versus Verlag Zürich.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Programme: BSc. Betriebsökonomie |BSc. Business Administration |BSc. International Business Management |BSc. Business Information Technology |BSc. Wirtschaftsinformatik |
Communication: ?Students are able to communicate their research to a professional audience in writing and online or in video form.  They are able to communicate with a large group of heterogenous internal and external stakeholders.
Content: This special Focus Module is part of the overall assignment given to each year's selected 'International Student Project 'teams Insight China  Focus India  connectUS and exploreASEAN. Each team is allocated specific tasks and topics as part of their project  but the following accounts for all: Students investigate and analyse the most important political  social and economic and/or technical developments within the defined region or filed of study. They further identify potential areas of interest for the projects (themes)  investigate the initial themes and define and investigate the core focus area  and deliver a professional business briefing document based on current business intelligence. Based on their research  students design a week-long expert seminar in Switzerland  design a progamme for an international study tour  and organise both. As part of the overal project brief  this special Focus Module's work is directed towards:  Conceptualization Project theme and concepts of preparatory week and onsite trip.
Description: ?This special Focus Module is part of the overall assignment given to each year's selected 'International Student Project' Teams Insight China  Focus India  connectUS and exploreASEAN. Each team is allocated specific tasks and topics as part of their project  but the following is true for all:  Students investigate and analyse the most important political  social and economic and/or technical developments within the defined region or filed of study. They further identify potential areas of interest for the projects (themes)  investigate the initial themes and define and investigate the core focus area  and deliver a professional business briefing document based on current business intelligence. Based on their research  students design a week-long preparatory expert seminar in Switzerland  design a programme for an international study tour  and organise both.
Judgement: ?Students are able to weigh the relative importance and impact of the socio-political  economic and cultural drivers of a defined topic area and judge how changes in these drivers may influence future developments in the topic area.
Knowledge: ?Students can explain the key socio-political  economic  cultural and technological drivers of a defined topic area.  They can research socio-political  economic and cultural elements of a defined target country  region or approved field of expertise using secondary and published sources (plus optionally expert interviews). They understand the current situation of a defined topic area in a given target country or region.  They understand the key historical precedents for the defined topic area.
Title: Module Description

Communication: Present solutions to BPM cases in a compelling manner (focus: medium)
Content: Strategic alignmentProcess governanceProcess improvementProcess innovationProcess and Case ModelingProcesses and DecisionsWorkflowmanagementBPM skills and rolesBPM cultureBPM cases
Description: As a holistic approach  business process management (BPM) covers various factors including strategic alignment  governance  lean management  modeling  people  and culture for operating  improving  and innovating business processes. The course introduces fundamental frameworks  models  and methods in BPM and applies them to real-world cases.
Judgement: Assess options for process improvement and innovation (focus: high) Assess BPM-related decisions in organizations (focus: medium)
Knowledge: Know the foundations of BPM and understand the relevance of BPM for organizational performance (focus: medium) Know key frameworks  models  and methods of BPM and understand when to apply them (focus: high)

Aptos  CA: Cody-Cassidy Press.OMG: CMMN Case Management Model and NotationVon Halle  B.  & Goldberg  L. (2010). The Decision Model: A Business Logic Framework Linking Business and Technology. Communication: ?Students areable to work within multicultural teams and interact with other stakeholdersable to put in the practice active listening and humble inquiry as well as giving and receiving feedback Focus: Medium
Content: ? Part 1: ExplorationUnit 1: Introduction to lean entrepreneurshipUnit 2: Ideas generation and opportunites recognition Part 2: FormationUnit 3: Key frameworks and modelsUnit 4: Customer discovery Part 3: ValidationUnit 5: Customer validationUnit 6: Entrepreneurial financeUnit 7: Legal issues  Part 4: ActionUnit 8:  Business plan
Description: Most entrepreneurs go about things differently. Their natural inclination is to put thinking into immediate action to see if it works. Lean entrepreneurship emphasizes developing an understanding of entrepreneurial thought  mindset  and action  and then progresses through idea generation  and screening for patterns to predict success  and which underlie entrepreneurial decision making for enterprise creation and growth.
Judgement: Students areable to identify problems needing a solutionable to validate and recognize business opportunitiesable to select  interpret  and judge information from stakeholdersable to identify ethical and legal issues of new business idea Focus: Medium
Knowledge: Understand entrepreneurship by doing entrepreneurship. Study  investigate  discuss  and experiment creative processes to generate and evaluate entrepreneurial ideas  then learn how to turn the idea into a real start-up (early stage) or to develop (incept) a new business concept for an existing company with an omnidirectional scope  or to start one's own business. Focus: Medium
Recommended Reading: ?Aulet B  (2013)  Disciplined Entrepreneurship  Wiley Blank  S.  Dorf  B.  (2012). The Startup Owner's Manual  1st  K&S Ranch  Inc.Bruce R. Barringer  R. Duane Ireland  (2016)  Entrepreneurship  5th Edition  Pearson Prentice Hall Publishing Co.Burns  P  (2011)  Entrepreneurship & Small Business: Start-up  growth & maturity  3rd Edition  Palgrave Macmillan.Osterwalder  A. et (2014)  Business Model Canvas  WileyRies E  (2017)  Lean Startup  1st  CurrencyScarborough  Norman M.  Upper Saddle River  NJ (2014)  Essentials of Entrepreneurship and Small Business Management  7th Edition  Pearson Prentice Hall Publishing Co.Schaper  M.  Volery  T.  Weber  P. Description: ?This module focuses on innovation management within existing companies  design thinking and modelling of new business ideas  and international entrepreneurship. The module combines research-based knowledge by developing innovative business ideas  including a prototype or similar application or platform  a minimum viable product.
Module Coordinator: Barbara Therese Miller|#216|#Andrew Mpeqa|#253|#Leng Khim (Lynn) Lim|#213
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?The students...   • ... can explain the outcomes of investment and financing decisions (Objective 3.1)   • ... can explain the results of analysis and budgeting based on the financial feedback loop (Objective 3.1)
Content: ?  Basics of Financial Mathematics  • Time value of money (future values  simple and compound interest  annuities  perpetuities)   • Risk  return  risk quantification   Introduction to Corporate Finance  • Real and financial assets   • Principal-agent problem   • Value maximization principle   Corporate Financing  • Debt financing (bond valuation  bond rate of return  bond yields)   • Equity Financing (stock valuation  stock markets  the dividend discount model)   • Issuing securities (initial public offering  rights issue)   Invesments/Capital Budgeting  • Net present value (present value  opportunity cost of capital  weighted average cost of capital)   • Discounted cash-flow analysis and other investment criteria (internal rate of return  payback method  profitability index)   • Weighted-average cost of capital and company valuation   • Economic Value Added   Special Topics  • Blockchain Applications in the Financial Sector: Case Study  Controlling  • The system of a financial controlling loop   • Analysis of current and future financial performances   • Budgeting bottom-up and top-down
Description: ?The guiding principle of the course is to provide the students with knowledge of how companies can raise up funds und invest these in projects that increase the company's value. The students will be acquainted with the main methods to evaluate different investment and financing decisions. In addition major company valuation methods will be applied in the course. For bigger companies  a financial controlling system as a permanent feedback loop is indispensable. This includes analysis  modification of strategies as well as strategy execution. The students understand the structure of financial controlling systems and are able to budget a company based on calculated income statements  cash flow statements as well as balance sheets.
Judgement: ?The students...   • ... are able to evaluate the different financial instruments (Objective 2.1)   • ... are able to evaluate various influence factors on the investment decisions (Objective 2.1)   • ... are able to evaluate the impact of the capital structure on the company's value (Objective 2.1)   • ... are able to evaluate the financial performance of a company (Objective 2.1)   • ... are able to interpret a calculated budget (Objective 2.1)
Knowledge: ?The students...   • ... know the different financing instruments and their advtantages and disadvantages   • ... know the principles of capital budgeting and company valuation   • ... know the link between investment and financing decsions and value creation   • ... are able to explain the structure of a financial feedback loop   • ... know the operational sequence of analysis and butgeding   • ... know how to calculate scheduled budgets
Recommended Reading: ?Brealey| Myers| Marcus: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students…communicate professionally both in presentations and in writing (obj. 3.1  3.2) use academic standards when presenting material (such as APA-citation)
Content: Students solve actual business problems of a client in small groups (3-5) and under the supervision of a lecturer. Students apply their project management knowledge  business and IT skills  as well as their social and communication skills. Students pay particular attention to the needs and expectations of the client  managing client expectations where appropriate. Furthermore  they manage and fulfill the expectations of a) the client  b) the supervising lecturer  and c) the project management lecturers. Coaching (by the supervising lecturer and the project management lecturers) is available but needs to be actively asked for by the students. Details are described in the "Guidelines on Practical Project".
Description: Students successfully completing the module Practical Project demonstrate an ability to apply acquired knowledge and solve practical issues autonomously  methodically and in an appropriate format. At the same time  the Practical Project is intended to achieve the following aims: Strengthening of specialist competencies: Recognizing the interconnectedness of a problem| tackling it in sufficient depth and on a scientific basis| applying and integrating acquired knowledge| filling gaps in knowledge. (Objective 2.1  2.2  4.1) Strengthening of social competencies: Accomplish projects autonomously in close collaboration with the other members of the team and the client. Strengthening of methodological skills: Applying project management methods and problem solving skills to the Practical Project.Strengthening of personal competencies: Coming to terms with one's performance limits| setting project management priorities| assuming responsibility. Students demonstrate they can handle pressure.
Judgement: ?Students...judge the feasibility of different approaches and solutions to the problem to be tackled during the projectprovide reasonable cost and time figures to proposed solution
Knowledge: ?Students...understand the needs and expectations of the client recall the ten knowledge areas of project management understand different project life cyclesrecall and update domain knowledge which is needed for successfully running the projectknow about academic requirements to be used in the project
Recommended Reading: ?Schwalbe  K. (latest edition): InformationTechnology Project Management. Cengage Learning International Edition
Title: Module Description

Module Name: Studienrichtung Finanzmanagement und Treuhand & Beratung Teil 2
Communication: ? • Finanzielle Informationen adressatengerecht auswählen und aufbereiten. • Finanzberichte prägnant und zielgruppengerecht präsentieren (Banken  Investoren  Gesellschaftern  Aktionören  Mitarbeitenden) • Aussagefähige Präsentationen erstellen und schriftlich wie mündlich überzeugend kommentieren. • Kollaborationswerkzeuge nutzen und produktiv verwenden. • Datenschutzverordnungen etc. einhalten.
Content: ?- Direkte Steuern Natürliche Personen - Direkte Steuern Juristische Personen  - Indirekte Steuern MWST  - Indirekte Steuern VST - Indirekte Steuern Grundstücke - Unternehmensbewertung - Rechtsformwahl - Instrumente der Unternehmens- und Wirtschaftsberatung
Description: Die  Studienrichtung Finanzmanagement und Treuhand / Consulting soll  Studierende zum Einstieg in die Treuhandbranche bzw. die kaufmännische  Führung eines KMU befähigen. Wie trifft man fundierte wirtschaftliche   Entscheidungen und welche Konsequenzen haben diese Entscheidungen  wiederum auf die finanziellen Verhältnisse (Gewinn  Cashflows  Steuern   Werte)? Die Studienrichtung baut auf den Grundlagen der vorhergehenden  Semester auf - Financial und Management Accounting  Corporate Finance   Financial Reporting und Controlling - und baut diese in Richtung der für  KMU relevanten Themen und Fragestellungen auf. So wird bei der  Rechnungslegung auf OR und Swiss GAAP FER fokussiert und praxisrelevante  Fragestellungen wie Erlösrealisierung  Berichterstattung in Anhang und  Lagebericht aber auch Konsolidierung behandelt. Im Bereich Steuern  stehen die wesentlichen Gewinn  Verkehrs- und Substanzsteuern auf dem  Programm. Im Bereich Consulting geht es im Schwerpunkt um Fragen der  Unternehmensbewertung. Auswirkungen der Digitalisierung auf diese  Bereiche werden parallel behandelt. Auch soft skills wie  Präsentationstechniken werden vermittelt.                 ?
Judgement: ? •  Finanzielle Informationen beurteilen können  sowohl quantitativ (i.e.  reicht die Höhe des Gewinns?) als auch qualititativ (i.e ist der Gewinn  die richtige Messgrösse) • beurteilen  welche steuerliche Risiken bei Gestaltungen bestehen und welche eingegegangen werden können und welche nicht. • Aussagen von Experten einordnen und werten können. • Potentiale in der Digitalisierung erkennen  bewerten und in ihren Folgen abschätzen. • Unternehmensbewertungen beurteilen  inhaltlich  fachlich und wertmässig.
Knowledge: ? • wissen  welche Unternehmen in der Schweiz nach welchen Gesetzen bzw. Standards ihre Rechnung legen müssen bzw. können. • die Vor- und Nachteile die mit der Wahl eines bestimmten Standards verbunden sind kennen und abschätzen. • wissen  wie die wesentlichen Geschäftsvorfälle nach OR und Swiss GAAP FER verbucht werden. • verstehen  wie das Steuersystem der Schweiz aufgebaut ist und wie  dieses mit anderen Steuerrechtskreisen zusammenwirkt oder in Konflikt  tritt • die wesentlichen Methoden zur Bewertung von Unternehmen kennen und die Besonderheiten von KMU dabei beachten
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Module Name: Balanced you - durch Achtsamkeit die eigene Resilienz stärken
Content: Belastungen im Alltag und deren Auswirkungen auf unser GehirnStress bedingte Veränderung von Verhalten und StimmungPersönlichkeit und Stressoren im AlltagVerständnis darüber  wie manWiderstandkraft (Resilienz)Aufmerksamkeit und KonzentrationRegenerationsfähigkeit selbstwirksam erhöhen kannIndividueller Rhythmus: Gleichgewicht zwischen Anforderungen und Regeneration (Chronobiologie)Achtsamkeit als wissenschaftlich gesicherte innere Haltung zur Förderung von Resilienz verstehenAchtsamkeit lernenAufmerksamkeit halten und steuern lernenWahrnehmungsfähigkeit verbessernbewusste Entscheidungen im Alltag treffen / strategische Achtsamkeit im AlltagMotivation  Selbstwirksamkeit und Selbstverantwortung im Kontext Stress und Stress FolgenNeurobiologie des Lernens: was ist mein ideales Setting? Umgang mit Emotionen und DruckEtablierung neuer Gewohnheiten auch unter belastenden UmständenAchtsamkeit und dessen Bedeutung auf Lebensstil-Themen
Description: In einer zunehmend digitalisierten und sich schnell verändernden Welt ist der Ausgleich von Ressourcen und der Aufbau von Resilienz unabdingbar. Dieser Kurs fördert das Bewusstsein der Studierenden für Belastungen und ein gutes Gleichgewicht zwischen Anforderungen und Regeneration. Die Studierenden lernen sich in belastenden Momenten  besser wahrzunehmen um auf Grundlage einer achtsameren Haltung bewusstere Entscheidungen zu treffen um sich langfristig zu stärken. Dieser Kurs bereitet die Studierenden aber auch auf die komplexen Anforderungen der Arbeitswelt und eine zunehmend volatilere Welt von morgen vor.
Judgement: Die Studierendenkönnen zusammen im Klassenverband über die Reflexion der eigenen Situation individuelle Handlungsmuster (Autopilot) erkennen  neue Handlungsoptionen erarbeiten und diese mit den Anderen diskutieren und sich darüber austauschen.
Knowledge: Die Studierendenkennen die wissenschaftlichen Grundlagen der Achtsamkeit und Achtsamkeits-Forschung sowie Resilienzhaben Grundkenntnisse zu den Stress-Anpassungsreaktionen  Prozessen im menschlichen Gehirn und daraus resultierenden Verhaltensmusternkennen die Auswirkungen von Achtsamkeit auf Resilienzhaben Grundkenntnisse zur Chronobiologie und Neurobiologiekennen den Unterschied zwischen formellen und informellen Achtsamkeits-Übungen für den Alltagkennen den Unterschied zwischen wertfreier Wahrnehmung und der Entstehung von Urteilen und Annahmen
Recommended Reading: ?Search Inside yourself  Chade-Meng Tan  ISBN 3641095492
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Module Name: Focus (IPH): Perspectives on International Business in Africa
Communication: Students are able to inform small and large groups and argue complex scenarios. They can present opposing views  based on carefully researched facts and data.
Content: ?Africa as a continent: past and present perceptions Africa as a continent: dynamic trends and outlookDoing business in sub-Saharan Africa onsite and online: opportunities and risksSelected industry clusters in sub-Saharan AfricaSelected issues on international business in sub-Saharan Africa
Description: Perspectives on International Business in Africa' is an intensive  higly interactive module aimed at providing students with fresh and stimulating insights into the past  present and future of international business in sub-Saharan Africa. The course will give an in-depth profile of sub-Saharan Africa  and covers areas such as opportunities and risks of doing business virtually and on-site  analyses selected industry clusters  and discusses current issues in the region.   The course will shed light on some pertinent assumptions and misunderstandings about Africa and Africans. By linking concrete data and research with accounts of real world experience  students are given the opportunity to build a broader understanding about the fascinating dynamics of the people and the economies in Africa.
Judgement: ?Students develop independent judgement based on discussions in the course  as well as literature and other sources.  From a long-term perspective  they will be able to support companies in devising expansion strategies for international markets.
Knowledge: ?Students can identify the dynamics impacting international businesses in Africa and outline relevant factors.
Recommended Reading: Leke  Chronga & Desvaux. Africa's Business Revolution: How to Succeed in the World's Next Big Growth Market  Harvard Business Review Press  2018. Adeleye  Ibeh  Kinoti & White. The Changing Dynamics of International Business in Africa  Palgrave Macmillan  2015. Robertson  Charles. The Fastest Billion: The Story Behind Africa's Economic Revolution  Renaissance Capital  2012. Selected World Bank Press Publications and Harvard Business Review Articles. Martin Meredith. The State of Africa: A History of the Continent Since Independence  Simon & Schuster  2013. Thinking Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahnmann  Farrar  Straus & Giroux. 2013
Title: Module Description

Module Name: CONTEXT (IPH) "We Are Not Them!": Identity Clashes in Europe
Communication: Students are able to:Effectively communicate information and argument in oral and written form.
Content: Identities and identity politicsEurope and its values: a historical overviewIdentity conflicts in Central & Eastern Europe – case studies  Identities in everyday life and popular culture – case studies
Description: Europe is strongly defined by common values and putatively similar cultures among its nations. More and more people  however  question these values and the “European Spirit”  which thus leads to clashes on both a political  economic and societal level. The module aims to discuss the meaning of identities and how they are used in politics and society. It looks at current developments mainly at the geographical borders of the continent to explain the centrifugal forces that seem to tear Europe apart.
Judgement: Students are able to:Judge the current developments in European politics as a result of identity politics and to differentiate different and diverging trends.
Knowledge: Students are able to:Define key concepts of identity and identification through discursive practices|Explain these concepts through their own  subjective position|Recognize elements of identity and identification in everyday culture|Discuss the importance of identity in current European developments.
Recommended Reading: ?TBD
Title: Module Description

Module Name: CONTEXT (IPH): Shape your future with Imp!act
Communication: to foster internal collaboration and communication by working in a team  to communicate ideas to the outside world and get into a dialogue with potential customers
Content: · Sustainable development (economic  social and environmental dimensions) · Alternative Project Management · Change-making · Social Entrepreneurship · Team work and radical collaboration Transformative learning allows students to use their talents  passions and disciplinary knowledge to develop a concrete project in an interdisciplinary team in order to tackle complex  real life problems and even global challenges by making a real difference locally.    Intensive Programme Outline: Evening 1  (5-9 pm) — Inspiration: Meet changemakers  who have found a way to tackle global challenges or have started their own projects. You will discuss and exchange ideas as a basis for the project work of the next days.  Day 2 — Release your creativity: Brainstorm your interests  passions  strengths and transform them into first project ideas. Pitch your new ideas  find a team and start setting up the projects right away.This session includes a leadership self-reflection process  several creativity sessions and the introduction to the methodologies used in the course.  Day 3 — Reality check: With your team  you set out to test your ideas right away  for example by organizing a first short and spontaneous campaign  by interviewing passersbys or by meeting potential partners. Day 4 — Make your project take off: Get feedback by experts and finalize your project. In the afternoon  you will pitch this very project to a jury who will not only evaluate your performance but also counsel you on how to continue after the course - if you wish to do so. In a final debriefing  the leadership attitude on how sustainable development can from theory be put into practice will be discussed. It includes a leadership reflection process on what the students take with them for their personal future/career beyond this class (harvesting).
Description: When it comes to tackling social  environmental and economic challenges of today  students with their ideas and motivation have a huge potential to become real changemakers. This class aims at equipping students with the practical experiences  tools and mindset required to turn good intentions into tangible actions. The very experience-driven and dynamic teaching approach of this class empowers the students to imagine  design and implement their own solutions for sustainability. Students even have the opportunity to start their own project in practice if they wish. The developped skill and mindset not only supports the individual role and duty of young citizens and but will be of helpful to future executives and leaders.
Follow up module: Facilitators:  Participants may apply to become facilitators for subsequent courses| applicants will be trained by 'euforia' (see 'Comments' section below)  and facilitate future programmes under the supervision of the coordinating lecturer: this work will yield 2 ECTS credits for training and programme organization and facilitation  allocated to the Context Module group.  Project Work Module:   Drafted projects may further be developed within the live 'Project  Work' module if the teams find sponsors.
Judgement: ?to acquire hard skills  such as alternative project management  including decision making   radical collaboration  team management  and marketing
Knowledge: ?to acquire the necessary knowledge and tools to conceptualize and implement an own entrepreneurial initiative for sustainable development in a team in collaboration with its target public and experts from research and professional practice
Recommended Reading: Basic reading (highly recommended before course start): Bornstein  David. 2007. How to Change the World: Social Entrepreneurs and the Power of New Ideas. Oxford University Press. Watch this video: http://www.ted.com/talks/simon_sinek_how_great_leaders_inspire_action.html Other readings (recommended to read before the class):  Osterwalder  Alexander & Pigneur  Yves. 2009. Business Model Generation: A Handbook For Visionaries  Game Changers  And Challenger. Preview:http://www.businessmodelgeneration.com/downloads/businessmodelgeneration_preview.pdf
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Negotiating and communicating an acquisition or merger deal from an international perspective. Co-operating in teams with differenct cultural backgrounds. Identifying and assessing cultural issues in business-relations and bilateral communication scenarios.
Content: ?Cross-cultural management workshopPreparation of industry sector and comparative company analysisPresentation of strategic  industry and financial analysis of the markets and companiesNegotiating  deal structuring  financing and letter of intent (LOI)Company valuation on the basis of different methodsStakeholder analysis  corporate social responsibility (CSR) analysis and integrationPresentations and written reports to the board of directors
Description: ?The focus of this module is to gain international exposure and competence by working in teams on an international project in the field of mergers and acquisitions (M&A). The project is an interdisciplinary  interactive  cross-cultural course focusing on industry and company consolidation. The aim is to merge a Swiss company with a foreign competitor. Emphasis will be placed on the following subjects:Advising on and carrying out industry and comparative (financial) analyses of two international companiesValuation of two real companies on the basis of different methods with a particular focus on the assessment and quantification of possible synergiesNegotiating and communicating an acquisition or merger deal from an      international perspectiveElaborating a reasonable deal structure  considering of different financing options of an M&A deal and summarizing the key terms and conditions in a letter of intent (LOI)Running a stakeholder and corporate social responsibility (CSR) analysis and setting up a plan for integrationConvincing the board of directors of the merits of the planned transaction with written reports and presentations
Judgement: ?Evaluating financial alternatives to investments such as M&A. Assessment and quantification of possible synergies in a merger of two companies. Determining a fair purchase price or exchange ration on the basis of the determined company values. Distinguishing important from unimportant information and recording the key points of the transaction in a LOI.
Knowledge: ?Being able to recognise the complexity of strategic financial decisions. Students are able to combine interdisciplinary knowledge and integrate quantitative with qualitative business administration.
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Students... will document and present the results of their group work
Content: ?Advanced    Topics of Machine Learning with the aspect of        using ML for practical application scenarios       Transfer Learning - additional insights       Insights into different application domains such as Natural language processing      Advanced Topics of Knowledge engineering    semantic technolgoy - additional insightssemantic web (RDFS  OWL) current application domains for rule based systems
Description: ?The module deepens the insight into the field of Artificial Intelligence and puts a focus on the state of the art knowledge engineering as well as machine learning methods and how they are currently applied in different fields of businesses.  As such it covers first some additional topics which are necessary to deepen the basic understanding from AIT part I  (which is a pre-requisite course) an enables the participants to make their own experiences with specific business applications. The student groups implement some prototypes and do some own experiments  which are presented in a final AIT conference day.
Judgement: ?Students... will be able to decide when which techniques can be applied
Knowledge: ?Students... will deepen their understanding of the principles of the current state-of-art techniques of artificial ntelligence

Title: Module Description

Programme: BSc. Betriebsökonomie |BSc. Business Administration |BSc. Wirtschaftsinformatik |BSc. Business Information Technology |BSc. International Business Management |
Communication: ?- effectively communicate within and about their activities - share the outcomes in a convincing and compelling presentation
Content: ?The Spring School offers a series of seminars and workshops around a specific theme (“current topic”) over a period of one week (“full-time”)  mixed with topic related excursions and visits. The theme of each Spring School will change from year to year. The related program will be available well in advance of the registration process. Exemplary  the program from February 9 - 14  2020  runs as follows: - Sunday: Arrival & Welcome (at 14.00 hrs.)| setting the scene| dinner| keynote speech - Monday – Thursday: expert talks & excursions| business lunch| group work with selected expert coaching| dinner| creative leisure sessions related to the topic - Friday: closing the scene & group work| working lunch| group presentations| farewell session
Description: ?The purpose of the Spring School is to strengthen the understanding and the role of business and responsibility as well as to raise the trinational awareness among students in the Tri-Rhena region and will be co-organized with the University of Basel. The Spring School will take place each February (usually week 6 or 7) before the start of the spring semester.  Students engage in full-time  intensive classes and activities related to a specific theme / predefined topic. The guiding principle of each Spring School will be around “Business & Responsibility”  reflecting both a practical and reflective approach to current topics. The specific theme for each Spring School will be announced well before the registration.
Judgement: ?- recognize the value of cultural and historical differences as they appear in the Tri-Rhena region - convey the Tri-Rhena experiences to a global context - be able to assess implementation consequences
Knowledge: ?Students can... understand the guiding principles around “Business & Responsibility” as applied to the specific theme of the Spring School
Recommended Reading: ?tba
Title: Module Description

Module Name: Silicon Valley as Heaven and Hell
Communication: ?Students write a report. Students write  read  hear and speak English.
Content: ?Discussion of Dave Egger's novel The Circle (2013) and a selection of academic and media texts on the novel  on the philosophical implications of IT and on American and Silicon Valley culture  ideology and history. Guided completion of a written report.
Description: ?Silicon Valley - some say "it's an innovative  meritocratic wonderland that rewards brilliant visionaries and just might save the world" (Tokumitsu 2018)  others consider Google  Apple etc. to be the harbingers of apocalypse. We will study American discourse on IT and social media by reading Dave Egger's novel The Circle (2013) and a selection of commentaries. Thus  the module offers students the opportunity to improve their English and to discuss aspects of IT from a political and cultural perspective.
Judgement: ?Students critique aspects of IT from a political and cultural perspective.
Knowledge: Students understand aspects of IT from a political and cultural perspective.aspects of American ideology and history and their implications for business and corporations.
Title: Module Description

Communication: Students ...use the correct technical terms and concepts regarding E-Business and Knowledge Management in written and oral communication (Obj. 3.1  3.2| R) state evidence-based opinions in open discussions (Obj. 3.1  3.2| R)
Content: Knowledge typologies and knowledge as a key factor for competitivenessFoundations  concepts and models of Knowledge ManagementKnowledge Management and Information Systems & ToolsKnowledge management practice casesSignificance of IT and e-business for business value creationE-Business applications in the corporate environment and in companies' interrelationshipsDigital transformation: E-business and its impact patternsE-Commerce and Customer Relationship Management (CRM)E-Procurement (of direct and indirect goods) and Electronic Data Interchange (EDI)E-Business management and the description of e-business models
Description: To achieve high levels of productivity that ensure today's standard of living  organisations have to contribute with their specialised services and products in extended and tightly integrated value creation networks. The added value of these networks is based on businesses' domain knowledge and their specific competencies  and  on the other hand  on the ability to coordinate the various stakeholders in a sophisticated manner - with networked information technology (IT or ICT) being a central means to support both aspects.    A company's competitive advantage draws mainly on the collective knowledge of its employees and managers  and knowledge management (KM) is the approach to leverage these resources systemically based on the identification  acquisition  development  dissemination and preservation of knowledge. Business processes are the basis for the coordination of the different parties involved in the value networks. Networked IT enables the creation and execution of effective processes and smart business models  which is known as E-Business. It encompasses everyday processes ranging from automated procurement processes of supermarkets to innovative sharing and brokerage concepts like Uber and Airbnb.
Judgement: Students ... are familiar with models and concepts of KM  such as Community of Practice and the Knowledge Spiral  and use them to analyse practice situations and cases compare the elements and use of e-business concepts and assess the potential of e-business for different organisations and different organisational scenariosare able to evaluate which e-business concept is useful depending on the organisation (Obj. 2.1  E)
Knowledge: Students ... explain and differentiate terms  taxonomies and characteristics of knowledgerecall and recognize the importance  role  purposes  drivers and benefits of knowledge management in organizations and businessesdescribe the role and importance of information technology and information systems for KMunderstand the significance of networked information technology for creating business value and the organization of cross-operational (or industry-wide) collaborationknow several e-business concepts for the collaboration in corporate groups as well as with customers and suppliers
Recommended Reading: ?Leimstoll  U.  Dannecker  A.  Knechtli  H.  Quade  M.  Tanner  C.  & Wölfle  R. (2018). E-Business in the Era of Digital Transformation. In R. Dornberger (Hrsg.)  Business Information Systems and Technology 4.0: New Trends in the Age of Digital Change (S. 81 - 101). Cham: Springer International Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-74322-6_6
Title: Module Description

Communication: Die Studierenden ... können die betrachteten mathematischen Zusammenhänge verbal und schriftlich darstellen.
Content: Vektorenlineare GleichungssystemeMatrizenEigenwerteEigenvektorenOrthogonalitätDistanzfunktionenNäherungsfunktionen
Description: Die Lineare Algebra wird auf moderne Art und Weise eingeführt  wobei die grundlegenden Konzepte der Vektoren  lineare Gleichungssysteme  Matrizen  Eigenwerte und Eigenvektoren  Orthogonalität sowie Abstand und Approximation behandelt werden. Neben der mathematischen Behandlung dieser Konzepte werden auch Informatik-Aspekte diskutiert. Der Kurs bildet die Grundlage für viele fortgeschrittene und moderne Themen wie künstliche Intelligenz  maschinelles Lernen  Data Science und Kryptographie.
Follow up module: ?Statistik und Wahrscheinlichkeit Business Intelligence IT Security
Judgement: Die Studierenden ... können (Zwischen-) Lösungen bei der Anwendung von Verfahren zur Lösung linearer Gleichungssystemen interpretieren.können die mathematische Basis von Anwendungen der linearen Algebra beurteilen
Knowledge: ?Die Studierenden ... kennen und verstehen die grundlegenden Konzepte der linearen Algebrakennen und verstehen die verschiedenen Operationen mit Vektoren und Matrizenkennen Grundlagen der Linearen Optimierung  insbesondere lineare Optimierungsprobleme und zugehörige Lösungsansätze. (Obj.2.1)
Recommended Reading: David Poole. Linear Algebra: A Modern Introduction. 4th Edition  Cengage Learning  2015.
Title: Modul Beschreibung

Communication: ?Students... use the marketing and social media terminology in a precise  specific and qualified way in written communication (Obj. 3.1  R)
Content: Basic Marketing terms and definitions  Sustainable marketing (social responsibility / ethics) Creating customer value understanding consumer and buyer behavior Analysis and marketing research (competitor and customer insights  industry dynamics) Marketing goals and marketing strategies Segmentation  targeting and positioning Marketing (Re-)Mix with all 8 P instruments Implementation and controlling of marketing plan Foundations of social media and social networks
Description: Today’s employees must have a broad understanding of marketing as the fundamental concept of market orientation for all entrepreneurial activities and business ventures. The course Marketing and Social Media will enable student to evaluate and apply various contemporary approaches to marketing activities and strategies for a successful sustainable brand building and business development in the 21st century. The module covers traditional marketing approaches  such as consumer behavior  segmentation  targeting and positioning but focuses on the extended digital marketing mix of all relevant 8 P instruments. Students will understand the power and impact of digital marketing tools in communications and Customer Relationship Management (CRM)  covering all ongoing developments of digitalization. Understanding the foundations  dynamics and use of social media for business purposes in general  and for marketing in particular  is becoming a more and more relevant part of the managerial skills set  and will be thus covered specifically in this module.   ?
Judgement: Students...based on practical situations  develop different approaches to marketing problems and evaluate them analyze and evaluate marketing strategies in case studies critically analyze social media arrangements and differentiate strategies. (Obj. 2.1| C).
Knowledge: Students understand the basic philosophy of marketing explain consumer behavior  customer insights and customer needs execute a marketing situation analysis develop a marketing strategy based on the key elements segmentation  targeting  differentiation and positioning outline the methods and steps in the marketing research process identify and design the elements of a marketing plan (with all elements of the marketing mix) develop and apply  a suitable marketing mix for a specific product or services list and explain the principles of marketing controlling   explain the foundations of social media and social network sites (Obj. 2.1  C).  explain key steps in planning and putting a social media strategy into practice
Recommended Reading: Additionally recommended  but NOT requested: Kotler  P.  Armstrong  G. (2018). Principles of Marketing  17th Edition. Global Edition. Pearson Education Limited.?
Title: Module Description

Communication: ?Discuss with managers and academians.
Content: ?The field trip in Autumn Semester is to Silicon Valley. In 2020 it is organized as a virtual trip with online sessions with company managers. The module consists of a predeparture seminar about the country and companies to be visitedcompany visits with the opportunity to talk with managersa de-briefing session after each company visitwriting a report about a related topic
Description: ?Field trips to Silicon Valley and South Africa open up opportunities for developing a global mindset.  Understanding other countries’ economic  social  political and cultural systems and imprints is key. During the field trips the students have the opportunity to talk with managers of various companies and visit universities.The field trip to Silicon Valley has a special focus on innovation| the field trip to South Africa deals primarily with diversity.
Judgement: ?The students understand commonalities and differences of the way of doing business. After the field trip to Silicon Valley the students are able to make decisions on how to start a business. The field trip to South Africa provides insights on how to lead people with different cultural background.
Knowledge: ?Understand other countries’ economic  social  political and cultural systems and imprints. During the field trip to Silicon Valley the students understand the differences in culture  investment and use of IT with respect to innovation. During the field trip in South Africa the students learn hwo to deal with people from different cultural background both as employees and customers and how to different types of economies in the country interact.
Title: Module Description

Simplifying and altering expressions and apply it on simple processes and programs (Boolean algebra). Part 2: Functions & Analysis Understanding the principles of mathematical description of economic models with functions and using equations and basic analysis for interpretation of these.

Title: Module Description

Communication: Students ...learn how to communicate in an academically well written text/paper their prepared topic  using the model of critical thinking. (3.1)
Content: ?In Tobit  each student choose a topic to investigate in depth. The student then summarizes the findings in a written report/paper. The goal is knowledge transfer: distill the results of detailed research into the most important information  such as might be required by management  and to present this information understandably in a written format  using different sources  as well as academic ones. (3.1 3.2) Tobit is an important part of the preparations for the bachelor thesis and the Academic Writing course  together with the Coaching sessions  students will learn the foundations of how to academically think and produce a well written academic text.
Description: This course is specifically designed to help students to prepare their ToBIT papers. Specifically  through this course students will learn how to:understand and use the model of critical thinking|understand  develop and use keywords|develop research questions|use four-five scientific databases  using keywords|be able to explain and experience the characteristics and the features of academic writing  doing writing exercises|learn about doing a literature review|acknowledge sources and references correctly|learn how to write good and complete paragraphs and sentences  as well as an abstract  an introduction  a conclusion|learn how to paraphrase  quote in-text and summarize  and avoid plagiarisms' temptations|learn how to develop an academic argument  sustained by a discussion|learn to use the APA-style|learn to use outlines and concept maps|experience Zotero  as a management tool for sources|
Judgement: ?The type of analysis required depends on the subject. Therefore students learn how to assess the quality of the different peer reviewed articles  chapters  texts  and other sources and how to select the relevant information from a diversified and rich collection of texts (2.1| 2.2)
Knowledge: Students ...learn to understand new ideas. Each student receives a topic to prepare  and each topic is supervised by an instructor and by the academic writing instructor.
Recommended Reading: ?yes - presented and provided in class and through Moodle|

Communication: ?Students ... …make small presentations about different IT topics... explain the relevance and potential of new technologies
Content: - Overview of Information Systems  Organizations and Strategy  - Overview of Ethical and Social Issues in Information Systems  - Overwiev of IT Infrastructure and Emerging Technologies  - Overview of Foundations of Business Intelligence  - Overview of Securing Information Systems  - Overview of Enterprise Applications  - Overview of E-Commerce  - Overview of Managing Knowledge and Decision Making  - Overview of Building Information Systems  - Overview of Managing Projects & Global Systems
Description: ?The goal of this module is to provide a broad overview of relevant tools  frameworks and standards at the beginning of the BIT course of studies. The course helps to establish a basic common understanding of BIT and to establish a common denominator for students coming from different business as well as IT backgrounds. Students will not only understand the importance and benefit of BIT for an enterprise  but also understand its overall complexity and the necessity to work with common abstractions and models to describe and manage them.
Follow up module: Business process managementEnterprise Systems       Enterprise Content ManagementAdvanced knowledge technologies
Judgement: ?Students ... … understand and decide between different scenarios of making  buying or renting IT systems. ... understand different solutions of how software and IT systems can be evaluated  designed  built  used  managed until they are de-committed… will be able to discuss strengths and weaknesses of different enterprise information systems  … will be able to describe the relations between different enterprise information systems (application landscape)
Knowledge: Students ... ... understand basic terms and concepts of BIT ... understand basic concepts of Informations Systems  Organizations and Strategy... understand basic concepts of Ethical and Social Issues in Information Systems... understand basic concepts of Informaiton Technology Infrastructure... understand basic concepts of System Applications... understand basic concepts of Building and Managing Systems
